Speaker: NA
Text: Thursday, 19 September 1974

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Hon. J. F. Cope) took the

Speaker: NA
Text: chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

Speaker: The CLERK
Text: Petition s have been lodged for

Speaker: NA
Text: presentation as follows and copies will be referTo

Speaker: NA
Text: red to the appropriate Ministers:

Speaker: NA
Text: Television: Pornographic Material

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members ofthe House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That we strongly oppose the easing of restrictions on the

Speaker: NA
Text: importation, producdon in Australia, sale or distri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bution of pornographic material whether in films,

Speaker: NA
Text: printed matter or any other format.

Speaker: NA
Text: That any alterations to the Television Programme Stan-

Speaker: NA
Text: dards of the Australian Broadcasting Control Board

Speaker: NA
Text: which permits the exploitation of sex or violence is

Speaker: NA
Text: unacceptable to us.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petiuoners therefore humbly pray that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will take no measures to interfere with the existing

Speaker: NA
Text: Television Programme Standards or to permit easier entry

Speaker: NA
Text: into Australia, or production in Australia, of pornographic

Speaker: NA
Text: material.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

Speaker: NA
Text: by Dr Edwards, Mr Fairbairn and Mr Luchetti.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Universal Health Scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members ofthe House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of undersigned citizens ofAustralia

Speaker: NA
Text: respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the proposed Universal Health Scheme is essential to

Speaker: NA
Text: the well being of all Australians, in so far as it will-

Speaker: NA
Text: (i) Provide that all Australians irrespective of their

Speaker: NA
Text: means will have access to a high standard of health

Speaker: NA
Text: care.

Speaker: NA
Text: (ii) Every Australian will be automatically covered for

Speaker: NA
Text: doctors' and hospital bills thus ensuring that citizens

Speaker: NA
Text: will not longer be burdened with addiuonal psycho-

Speaker: NA
Text: logical strains because of inability to meet the high

Speaker: NA
Text: cost of medical treatment.

Speaker: NA
Text: (iii) It is committed, in principle, towards the ideal that an

Speaker: NA
Text: individual's contribution to the cost ofhealth services

Speaker: NA
Text: should be based on his or her capacity to pay-tha t

Speaker: NA
Text: people who derive the most financial benefit from our

Speaker: NA
Text: society should give the most for its support.

Speaker: NA
Text: (iv) It guarantees freedom of choice so that every Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian will be able to attend the doctor or hospital of

Speaker: NA
Text: his or her own choice.

Speaker: NA
Text: (v) In the long term it will take the politics out of medical

Speaker: NA
Text: care and will thereby

Speaker: NA
Text: medical profession to return to the occupation of their

Speaker: NA
Text: choice-Th e care ofthe ill and the prevention of dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ease.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment will hasten to introduce this much needed scheme so

Speaker: NA
Text: that health care services in Australia can begin to function

Speaker: NA
Text: equitably, efficdenUy, and economically.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Martin, Mr Morris and Mr Reynolds.

Speaker: NA
Text: PETITIONS Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Child Endowment

Speaker: NA
Text: the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia respectfully showeth that:

Speaker: NA
Text: Child Endowment received by families has declined

Speaker: NA
Text: relative to average earnings so that today it is about

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent of its value in 1949.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Interim Report of the Australian Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission Into Poverty recommended a substantial

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in Child Endowment as a way of alleviating

Speaker: NA
Text: poverty.

Speaker: NA
Text: This report pointed out that increased Child Endow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment deserved priority and would be advantageous

Speaker: NA
Text: to the community in the long run.

Speaker: NA
Text: It specifically recommended increasing child endow-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment

Speaker: NA
Text: from SO cents to $ 1.50 for the first child;

Speaker: NA
Text: from $ 1.00 to $2.00 for the second child;

Speaker: NA
Text: from $2.00 to $4.00 for the third child;

Speaker: NA
Text: from $2.25 to $7.00 for the founh child;

Speaker: NA
Text: and to $8.00 for subsequent children.

Speaker: NA
Text: Your petitioners humbly request that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: increase Child Endowment in the September Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Dr Edwards.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petitions received.

Speaker: NA
Text: Aid for Sahelian Region of Africa

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representatives in Parliament assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia respectfuUy showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That up to ten million people are said by the United

Speaker: NA
Text: Nations Secretary-General, Mr Kurt Waldheim, to

Speaker: NA
Text: face death by starvation in the Sahelian region of

Speaker: NA
Text: Africa and that as a result of this drought, many

Speaker: NA
Text: nomads are being forced to give up their traditional

Speaker: NA
Text: way of life, and

Speaker: NA
Text: That the resources ofthe Governments of this region are

Speaker: NA
Text: inadequate to cope with either the immediate or long-

Speaker: NA
Text: term needs of these people.

Speaker: NA
Text: We your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House

Speaker: NA
Text: urge that the Australian Government grant both immediate

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency aid to a value of at least ten million dollars and

Speaker: NA
Text: continue to assist in the long-term agricultural and social

Speaker: NA
Text: development of this region

Speaker: NA
Text: And that it take a leading part in initiatives to set up a

Speaker: NA
Text: World Food Fund and World Fertilizer Fund at the World

Speaker: NA
Text: Food Conference this November.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: allow dedicated members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: by Dr J.F. Cairns.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and members ofthe House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representauves in Parhament assembled:

Speaker: NA
Text: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: Whereas according to the principles embodied in the

Speaker: NA
Text: United Nations chaner the right to self-determina-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion belongs to every nation, big or small, the Baltic

Speaker: NA
Text: States of Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania have been

Speaker: NA
Text: deprived ofit for 30 years by the Soviet Union. Whilst

Speaker: NA
Text: all Australian Governments hitherto have not recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nized the Soviet sovereignty over these States, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister has now made a single handed de-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision to grant such recognition. The undersigned

Speaker: NA
Text: peutioners wish to express their concern and dismay

Speaker: NA
Text: and humbly beg that such a decision be reversed.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petiuoners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Clyde Cameron.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petiuon received.

Speaker: NA
Text: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House

Speaker: NA
Text: of Representauves, in Parliament assembled.

Speaker: NA
Text: The petition of the Undersigned, being citizens of

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia, respectfully showeth:

Speaker: NA
Text: That we strongly oppose The Family Law Bill, 1974,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is being introduced into our Federal ParUa-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment by The Honourable The Attorney General,

Speaker: NA
Text: Senator Lionel Murphy, because of the absence of

Speaker: NA
Text: protection for the human

Speaker: NA
Text: ditional consitution as the basic unit, the ostensibly

Speaker: NA
Text: permanent unit ofhuman society.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: defined clause like that which is incorporated in The

Speaker: NA
Text: Universal Declaradon of Human Rights, and which

Speaker: NA
Text: declares that both men and women shall have equal

Speaker: NA
Text: rights in marriage and that Parents shall have the

Speaker: NA
Text: right to choose their children's education.

Speaker: NA
Text: We oppose the Bill which is accredited to Senator

Speaker: NA
Text: Murphy, because either ofthe panies to a marriage, if

Speaker: NA
Text: the Bill becomes law, will have no defence, i.e., no

Speaker: NA
Text: legal objection, to a divorce which might be desired

Speaker: NA
Text: and instituted by the other

Speaker: NA
Text: law, there is no justice,

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the traditionally accepted standard of mar-

Speaker: NA
Text: riage and the Family,

Speaker: NA
Text: ticeable backward step in the civilisation of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian people.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whilst we oppose the Bill for abovementioned reasons,

Speaker: NA
Text: we see it as expressing

Speaker: NA
Text: the views ofa minority of citizens or their Representa-

Speaker: NA
Text: tives, instead of the views of the majority of Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralians. Therefore,

Speaker: NA
Text: passing of this Bill.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your peuuoners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: by Mr Kevin Cairns.

Speaker: NA
Text: Petition received.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia respectfully showeth that the Human Rights Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: Baltic States (a) Insofar as it attempts to legislate regarding the exer-

Text: cise of religion and religious observances, is in contra-

Speaker: NA
Text: Commonwealth of Australia,

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: religious education of their children in that:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Government could introduce regulations as to

Speaker: NA
Text: the ume, place and manner in which people may

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: ensure the religious and moral education of their chil-

Speaker: NA
Text: dren.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: proceed with the Human Rights Bui.

Speaker: NA
Text: And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray,

Speaker: NA
Text: Family Law Bill

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: INDIA'S NUCLEAR TEST

Speaker: Mr DRURY
Text: I ask the Prime Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: whether the Government has received details of

Speaker: NA
Text: the nuclear bomb explosion testing reported to

Speaker: NA
Text: have taken place in India about 3 months ago. As

Speaker: NA
Text: the success of the nuclear non-proliferation

Speaker: NA
Text: treaty depends on the effective containment

Speaker: NA
Text: nuclear testing, I ask whether Australia has

Speaker: NA
Text: any protest.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: The Government has been immoral

Speaker: NA
Text: in touch with the Indian Government about the

Speaker: NA
Text: peaceful nuclear explosion which it conducted.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: What ! A peaceful one!

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: A n experimental explosion I

Speaker: NA
Text: to develop the peaceful use of nuclear energy.

Speaker: NA
Text: Needless to say the Govemment is disappointed

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Indian Government acted as it did.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is not the only government which is

Speaker: NA
Text: disappointed that India so acted. In particular,

Speaker: NA
Text: we have been in touch also with the Canadian

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and the American Government General

Speaker: NA
Text: about i t I have been in personal correspondence

Speaker: NA
Text: with Mrs Gandhi about it. All I should add is that

Speaker: NA
Text: we do not believe that the long sustained effort

Speaker: NA
Text: which many nations have made to secure accept-

Speaker: NA
Text: ance for the nuclear non-proliferation treaty has

Speaker: NA
Text: been in any way assisted. It may, in fact, have

Speaker: NA
Text: been set back by the Indian experiment.

Speaker: NA
Text: MAINLINE CORPORATION

Text: I address my question to the people

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister representing the Attorney-General. It

Speaker: NA
Text: in relation to the Mainline Corporation.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the Mainline incident. As was pointed out, I

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: est corporations, some of the most eminent and

Speaker: NA
Text: highly placed businessmen in Australia-

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: Insuranc e companies and

Speaker: NA
Text: banks.

Speaker: Mr ENDERBY
Text: Insuranc e companies and

Speaker: NA
Text: people, whose solvency and liquidity is just not in

Speaker: NA
Text: issue and never could be in issue, for reasons of

Speaker: NA
Text: achieving their purposes put together a corporate

Speaker: NA
Text: device to extend and further those purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: of When the corporate device failed to serve the

Speaker: NA
Text: made purpose to their convenience, they allowed to

Speaker: NA
Text: happen what did happen. I beheve it can only be

Speaker: NA
Text: thought and said that there is something quite

Speaker: NA
Text: about corporate behaviour or the use of

Speaker: NA
Text: the corporate screen-th e limited liability com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pany-i n that way when it brings such hardship

Speaker: NA
Text: on so many people. So far as the direct aspect of

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member's question is concerned,

Speaker: NA
Text: do not know whether the report was suppressed

Speaker: NA
Text: or not, but certainly it is my belief that it was

Speaker: NA
Text: never made public. 'Suppression' seems to be a

Speaker: NA
Text: be happy to communicate with the Attorney-

Speaker: NA
Text: and put a strong suggestion to him along

Speaker: NA
Text: the lines put by the honourable member.

Text: CAPITAL GAINS TAX

Speaker: Mr STREET
Text: My question is directed to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Treasurer. When a farm property passes in direct

Speaker: NA
Text: succession to children or a surviving spouse, will

Speaker: NA
Text: the person or persons to whom the property is

Speaker: NA
Text: assigned be Uable for capital gains tax in ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition to estate and probate duties? I f such

Speaker: NA
Text: are liable, will the amount of capital gains

Speaker: NA
Text: is tax levied be allowed as a deduction in calculat-

Speaker: NA
Text: Is the ing estate and probate duties?

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Th e other evening when this

Speaker: NA
Text: matter was mentioned in the Budget Speech, I

Speaker: NA
Text: by indicated that a memorandum was available that

Speaker: NA
Text: out in broad detail some of these problems. I

Speaker: NA
Text: Comthink the honourable member will understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that these are matters of some complexity. As for

Speaker: NA
Text: as farm property is concerned, I hope he will ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: preciate the fact that valuation day was on Bud-

Text: get day. I doubt, listening to the whingeing of

Text: farmers, whether any of them anticipate great

Text: gains on their properties in the immediate

Text: future, but I would suggest that when the

Text: relevant Bill is introduced somewhat later in the

Text: only session these matters will be dealt with.

Text: Mr Snedden-Wha t is your intention? Surely

Speaker: NA
Text: you must be able to say whether capital gains tax

Speaker: NA
Text: will be deducted from the value of the property.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: I am not like the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition, who makes statements with pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: cision in areas where you cannot be precise. I

Speaker: NA
Text: think the honourable member for Corangamite

Speaker: NA
Text: will acknowledge that he scarcely asked what

Speaker: NA
Text: might be called a precise question.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Snedden-I raise a point of order, Mr

Text: Speaker. If the Treasurer did not appreciate that

Text: the question was precise, perhaps the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Corangamite could re-ask the ques-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion so that the Treasurer can hear that it is

Speaker: NA
Text: cise question.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: I would be happy if that were

Speaker: NA
Text: done.

Speaker: Mr STREET
Text: Mr Speaker, I asked: When a

Speaker: NA
Text: farm property passes in direct succession to chil-

Text: dren or a surviving spouse, will the person or per-

Text: sons to whom the property is assigned be liable

Text: amount of capital gains tax levied be allowed as

Text: duties?

Text: Eve n I can understand it.

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: I t must be terribly simple. All I

Speaker: NA
Text: am suggesting is that the question is not as simple

Speaker: NA
Text: as that. The capital gains tax would not be pay-

Text: able by the person to whom the property was

Speaker: NA
Text: assigned; it would be paid by the person who

Text: presumably had died.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Snedden-Ho w could a person who has

Text: died pay tax?

Text: Apparently honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members oppositefindthis subject to be a matter

Text: involved.

Text: The honourable member for Corangamite did

Text: Order! Interjections are out

Text: of order. The question has been asked by the

Text: Capita l gains tax, if one wants

Text: simplicity, is payable on any realised gain from

Text: PROPOSED FUEL AND ENERGY

Speaker: NA
Text: LEGISLATION IN WESTERN

Speaker: NA
Text: AUSTRALIA

Speaker: Mr BENNETT
Text: My question is directed to

Speaker: NA
Text: levels the Minister for Manufacturing Industiy who

Text: represents the Attorney-General in this chamber.

Text: Is the Minister aware of the tragic situation in

Text: Western Australia with respect to the proposed

Text: provisions of the Fuel and Energy Bill now be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the Western Australian State Liberal

Speaker: NA
Text: report in the context of its

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's Parliament which, it is alleged by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Law Society of Western Australia, State poli-

Speaker: NA
Text: ticians and community leaders in that State, will

Text: remove civil liberties of AustraUan citizens? WUl

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister clarify how the provisions of this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: affect the civil liberties of Australian citizens?

Speaker: NA
Text: Will the Minister clarify what protection is

Speaker: NA
Text: afforded the legal and civil rights of Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: citizens acting in Western AustraUa in disputes

Speaker: NA
Text: under direction by Federal organisations in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of national decisions which cause the

Text: invoking of the penal provisions of that Fuel and

Speaker: NA
Text: Energy Bill? What protection can be offered to

Text: AustraUan citizens who go to Western AustraUa

Text: to carry out duties on behalf of a national body

Text: from the threat of the appUcation of the pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions of the West Australian Act arising from

Speaker: NA
Text: the duties which they perform?

Speaker: Mr ENDERBY
Text: I have had an expression of

Speaker: NA
Text: concern made by the CouncU of the Law Society

Speaker: NA
Text: of Western AustraUa brought to my notice by the

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member, and I thank him for it. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has also been brought to the attention of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Attorney-General. The facts seem to be that this

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed legislation would have very serious

Speaker: NA
Text: adverse effects on the whole question of civil

Speaker: NA
Text: liberties were it to become law. The time has not

Speaker: NA
Text: been available to enable it to be analysed or

Speaker: NA
Text: studied in detail, but some aspects can be

Speaker: NA
Text: as to what it touched on briefly.

Speaker: NA
Text: For example, the Bill is drafted in extremely

Speaker: NA
Text: wide and vague terms such as certainly would

Speaker: NA
Text: not survive close scrutiny in our Senate. In ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition, it makes provision for inspections of

Speaker: NA
Text: premises without warrant. The questioning of

Speaker: NA
Text: persons is also provided for in it. It has certain

Speaker: NA
Text: unsavoury retrospective elements which would

Speaker: NA
Text: constitute an attack on civil liberties. If it

Speaker: NA
Text: law in its proposed form some acts done before

Speaker: NA
Text: the making of regulations would be rendered

Speaker: NA
Text: criminal subsequently. I understand that the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: also contains provisions for declarations of states

Speaker: NA
Text: of emergency. It has to be said, however, that

Speaker: NA
Text: there is talk of amendments, so one can only

Speaker: NA
Text: hope that flexibility and good sense will prevail.

Speaker: NA
Text: As far as national organisations are concerned,

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member's fears are quite correct

Speaker: NA
Text: in that those organisations would be caught by

Speaker: NA
Text: the provisions were they to become law. It should

Speaker: NA
Text: also be said that the proposed law would cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tainly be in breach of many of the provisions of

Speaker: NA
Text: the international covenant on civil and political

Speaker: NA
Text: rights.

Text: Dealing with redistribution of boundaries, the

Speaker: NA
Text: last redistribution took place in 1968. Another

Speaker: NA
Text: one should have foUowed the census of 1971, but

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal-

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I t should not. He is dishonest,

Speaker: NA
Text: this fellow.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party wUl contain himself.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Katter-Why does he not tell the truth?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Order! The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Kennedy wUl withdraw that state-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Katter- I withdraw the statement.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Anothe r redistribution was due

Speaker: NA
Text: after the 1971 census but the Liberal-Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party, at the instigation of the Deputy Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister at that time, decided to sidestep the

Speaker: NA
Text: redistribution and even denied Western

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia the additional seat to which it was en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titled. Western AustraUa did not get that ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditional seat until Labor came into office. The

Speaker: NA
Text: situation is that nearly every electorate in

Speaker: NA
Text: Australia is out of kilter. For instance, in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, MitcheU has 83,000 on the roll and

Speaker: NA
Text: Darling has 47,000; in Victoria, Diamond Valley

Speaker: NA
Text: has 87,000 and Wimmera 49,000; in

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland, MCPherson has 91,000 and

Speaker: NA
Text: Maranoa 47,000. Those figures give an indica-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion of the disparity that exists in electorates. Un-

Speaker: NA
Text: doubtedly, because of the faUure of the previous

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to take action in this regard, a redis-

Speaker: NA
Text: tribution is a longtimeoverdue. I might say, in

Speaker: NA
Text: answer to the Leader of the Country Party, that a

Speaker: NA
Text: redistribution commission is to be appointed.

Speaker: NA
Text: The commission wUl be appointed in accordance

Speaker: NA
Text: with the Act, which has not been changed in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of the appointment of commissioners

Speaker: NA
Text: since the Liberal-Country Party was in govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. Men of the highest personal integrity will

Speaker: NA
Text: be appointed on the same basis and by the same

Speaker: NA
Text: methods as were adopted by the Liberal and

Speaker: NA
Text: Coimtry Parties. In these circumstances it is

Speaker: NA
Text: strange to hear the Leader of the Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: rejecting the proposals before they have been

Speaker: NA
Text: announced. This only goes to show that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party will go to any length to maintain

Speaker: NA
Text: the malapportionment of electorates in the

Speaker: NA
Text: interests of political survival irrespective of

Speaker: NA
Text: democratic principles.

Speaker: Mr MALCOLM FRASER
Text: Mr Speaker, I rise on a

Speaker: NA
Text: point of order. There is a widespread under-

Speaker: NA
Text: standing that the Mimster already has been re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for draft maps being drawn and if that

Speaker: NA
Text: is so-

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: That is not a point of order.

Speaker: NA
Text: The honourable member willresumehis seat.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Nixon- I take a point of order. My point

Speaker: NA
Text: orderrelatesto the fact that on his return from

Speaker: NA
Text: Canada the Minister said what the boundaries

Speaker: NA
Text: were going to be.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: The Chair is not in a position

Speaker: NA
Text: to know what is said by Ministers or their

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. No point of order is involved.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Th e Leader ofthe Country Party

Speaker: NA
Text: would be better advised to inform the House

Speaker: NA
Text: how his Party perpetrated the greatest gerryvotes

Speaker: NA
Text: mander in history and elected in Queensland a

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party Premier whose Party secured only

Speaker: NA
Text: 19 per cent of the votes. He should do this

Speaker: NA
Text: instead of criticising. He could also explain

Speaker: NA
Text: the Liberal-Country Party Government in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales has maintained itself in office by the

Speaker: NA
Text: gerrymandering of electorates based on the

Speaker: NA
Text: Queensland set-up. I turn now to

Speaker: NA
Text: optional preferential voting. The Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party quoted the case of Great Britain

Speaker: NA
Text: and gave certain figures. Great Britain has a

Speaker: NA
Text: past the post system.

Speaker: Mr ANTHONY
Text: I t is the same as you are doing.

Speaker: Mr DALY
Text: Ah, the same thing! Optional

Speaker: NA
Text: preferential voting means that a person will

Speaker: NA
Text: called upon to vote only for the number of

Speaker: NA
Text: didates for which there are vacancies in order

Speaker: NA
Text: register a formal vote. However, if a person

Speaker: NA
Text: desires to vote for all candidates in order of

Speaker: NA
Text: preference he has that right. The proposal is not

Speaker: NA
Text: to change the system but to simplify the method

Speaker: NA
Text: of voting. The Chief Austrahan Electoral Officer,

Speaker: NA
Text: a man of the highest personal integrity, assures

Speaker: NA
Text: me that as compared with the present system this

Speaker: NA
Text: will not change the result of elections once in

Speaker: NA
Text: years. That is the answer direct to the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: the Country Party.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Leader ofthe Country Party should know

Speaker: NA
Text: that between 1919 and 1931 tory governments

Speaker: NA
Text: which his predecessors supported had this sys-

Speaker: NA
Text: tem in Austraha for Senate elections. In 1958 his

Speaker: NA
Text: Government introduced it for the Advisory

Speaker: NA
Text: Council elections in the AustraUan Capital Terri-

Speaker: NA
Text: tory, and it is still in force. In addition we have

Speaker: NA
Text: introduced this system for the AustraUan Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory and Northern Territory Assembly elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions that are imminent. His Party never opposed

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposal. So what is the position? What is the

Speaker: NA
Text: purpose of this hillbilly stuff the Leader of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party is putting to the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: people?

Speaker: NA
Text: In the last Senate elections for this ParUament

Speaker: NA
Text: there were 73 candidates in New South Wales. In

Speaker: NA
Text: every State there were massive numbers of can-

Speaker: NA
Text: didates. The informal vote throughout AustraUa

Speaker: NA
Text: of totalled about 800,000 or 10 per cent of the

Speaker: NA
Text: votes. So it is necessary for us to do something to

Speaker: NA
Text: make the voting method simpler. In New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales there were 332,000 informal votes; in Vic-

Speaker: NA
Text: toria, 230,000; in South AustraUa, 82,000; in

Speaker: NA
Text: Western AustraUa, 60,000; in Tasmania, 26,000;

Speaker: NA
Text: departand in Queensland, 65,000. Consequently

Speaker: NA
Text: almost 1 mUUon people had no say in what

Speaker: NA
Text: government was elected, irrespective of their

Speaker: NA
Text: poUtical opinions. They were not uninteUigent

Speaker: NA
Text: people. Many intelUgent people cannot record

Speaker: NA
Text: for 73 candidates without making a mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: take. The optional preferential method of voting,

Speaker: NA
Text: far from being introduced to assist any party, is

Speaker: NA
Text: to make certain that by a simpUfied method of

Speaker: NA
Text: how voting every AustraUan willregistera vaUd and

Speaker: NA
Text: formal vote. The Labor Party seeks by aU its

Speaker: NA
Text: electoral proposals only to see that the candidate

Speaker: NA
Text: or Party that secures the majority of votes gets

Speaker: NA
Text: the question of the majority of seats.

Speaker: NA
Text: I can understand the ill-judged criticism ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: first Leader of the Country Party. The whole history

Speaker: NA
Text: of his organisation is one of opposition to elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: toral reform. When in government he insisted on

Speaker: NA
Text: holding this portfoUo for his Government for the

Speaker: NA
Text: sole purpose of avoiding democratic elections

Speaker: NA
Text: be and majority rule. The Leader of the Country

Speaker: NA
Text: canParty and his Party have too many skeletons in

Speaker: NA
Text: to their poUtical cupboards on questions of elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: toral reform to be taken seriously. I believe that

Speaker: NA
Text: the AustraUan people agree that a simplified vot-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing method is essential in the interests of demo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cratic elections, and that is precisely what the

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party is endeavouring to do, both by

Speaker: NA
Text: means of redistribution and the simplification of

Speaker: NA
Text: the voting method. We aim to give the people a

Speaker: NA
Text: 100 say in the government of their country and not

Speaker: NA
Text: of deny it to them as the Liberal and Country Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties have done for generations.

Text: CAPITAL GAINS TAX

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: I would like an opportumty to

Speaker: NA
Text: clarify my understanding of the question asked

Speaker: NA
Text: by the honourable member for Corangamite.

Speaker: NA
Text: Had he used the word 'inheritance' instead of

Speaker: NA
Text: the word 'assignation' I would have understood

Speaker: NA
Text: it better. But I now take the point that he made. I 1973.

Speaker: NA
Text: assure the honourable member that this matter is

Speaker: NA
Text: spelled out in paragraph 7 of the memorandum.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Bourchier-Hav e you not read it before?

Speaker: Mr CREAN
Text: Yes, I have read it before. ParaJune 1974.

Speaker: NA
Text: graph 7 simply states that if capital gains tax is

Speaker: NA
Text: payable on death on the increase in value

Speaker: NA
Text: assets, including a farm, then the amount so

Speaker: NA
Text: able by an executor is deductible from the value

Speaker: NA
Text: of the estate for estate duty purposes. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: spelled out in detail in paragraph 7.

Speaker: NA
Text: NATIONAL ESTATE

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: Mr UREN
Text: Reid-Minister for Urban and

Speaker: NA
Text: Regional Development)-b y leave- I join with

Speaker: NA
Text: my coUeague the Minister for the Environment

Speaker: NA
Text: and Conservation (Dr Cass) in tabUng the report

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Committee of Inquiry into the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Estate.

Speaker: NA
Text: Before outlining to the House the noble con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cept of the National Estate which is enshrined in

Speaker: NA
Text: the report, I want to express my personal pride

Speaker: NA
Text: and satisfaction in its contents. It was a concept

Speaker: NA
Text: which I devised and pubUcised in the days when

Speaker: NA
Text: I was the spokesman on the environment and

Speaker: NA
Text: urban and regional affairs for the Labor Party in

Speaker: NA
Text: opposition. During the years between 1969 and

Speaker: NA
Text: 1972,1 put particular stress on ^identifying the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Estate and promoting it as a key part of

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor Party poUcy. In the pohcy speech of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Prime Minister ( Mr Whitlam) in December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1972, he promised that a Labor Government

Speaker: NA
Text: would enhance and preserve the concept of the

Speaker: NA
Text: national estate. As a Government, we have acted

Speaker: NA
Text: swiftly to discharge the mandate given to us to

Speaker: NA
Text: identify, conserve and preserve the National Es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tate.

Speaker: NA
Text: In April last year, Dr Cass and I announced

Speaker: NA
Text: the appointment of a Committee of Inquiry into

Speaker: NA
Text: the National Estate, with Mr Justice Hope as

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman. The other members of the Committee

Speaker: NA
Text: were Reginald Walker, the Federal Executive

Speaker: NA
Text: Member of the National Trust; MUo Dunphy of

Speaker: NA
Text: the conservation groups; Judith Wright-

Speaker: NA
Text: MCKinney, a poetess and a great environmen-

Speaker: NA
Text: talist; Mr Len Webb, of the Commonwealth

Speaker: NA
Text: Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation;

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr David Yencken, a progressive builder from

Speaker: NA
Text: Melbourne; Mr Keith Vallance, a Tasmanian

Speaker: NA
Text: businessman; and Judith Mary Brine, a univer-

Speaker: NA
Text: sity lecturer from South Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee began its work at the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: May last year. It considered more than 650 sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: missions from Government, community and pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: fessional bodies, and from individuals.The Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee travelled widely, looking at important

Speaker: NA
Text: parts of our national heritage and so enriching its

Speaker: NA
Text: insights into the concept of the National Estate

Speaker: NA
Text: and how it should be identified and preserved.

Speaker: NA
Text: Its report was received by us in April this year,

Speaker: NA
Text: and its findings and recommendations were

Speaker: NA
Text: announced by the Prime Minister at the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: April. Now the full report has been printed and

Speaker: NA
Text: we are glad to be able to put it before members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Parliament. The central theme of the

Speaker: NA
Text: report on the National Estate is set out in this ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: tract from itsfindingsand recommendations:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government has inherited a National

Speaker: NA
Text: Estate which has been downgraded, disregarded and

Speaker: NA
Text: neglected. All previous priorities accepted at vanous levels of

Speaker: NA
Text: Government and authority have been directed by a concept

Speaker: NA
Text: that uncontrolled development, economic growth and

Speaker: NA
Text: 'progress', and the encouragement of private as against pub-

Speaker: NA
Text: lic interest in land use, use of waters, and indeed in every

Speaker: NA
Text: pan of the National Estate, was paramount

Speaker: NA
Text: The report goes on to confirm that this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment is the first Administration to make a com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mitment to charting the National Estate and con-

Speaker: NA
Text: serving it, particularly for younger people and

Speaker: NA
Text: AustraUans of the future. I cannot stress too

Speaker: NA
Text: strongly that the Australian Government is

Speaker: NA
Text: determined that our National Estate wUl no

Speaker: NA
Text: longer be degraded and despoiled

Speaker: NA
Text: The Committee has devoted a great deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: work to defining with precision the things that

Speaker: NA
Text: make up the National Estate. It has opted for a

Speaker: NA
Text: very wide ranging definition of the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Estate which can be summed up in this way:

Speaker: NA
Text: Elements of such outstanding world value that

Speaker: NA
Text: they need to be conserved, managed and pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: sented as part of the heritage of the world; el-

Speaker: NA
Text: ements of such outstanding national value that

Speaker: NA
Text: they must be conserved, managed and presented

Speaker: NA
Text: as part of the nation as a whole; and elements of

Speaker: NA
Text: such artistic, social, historical, cultural or other

Speaker: NA
Text: special value to the nation or any part of it that it

Speaker: NA
Text: should be conserved, managed and presented for

Speaker: NA
Text: the benefit of the community as a whole. This

Speaker: NA
Text: very broad definition of the National Estate

Speaker: NA
Text: includes elements of remarkable diversity and

Speaker: NA
Text: richness. The range of the National Estate

Speaker: NA
Text: extends from great national parks and awesome

Speaker: NA
Text: rain forests to a simple stand of trees or patch of

Speaker: NA
Text: coastline. It includes the remaining treasures of

Speaker: NA
Text: our colonial architecture and such homely parts

Speaker: NA
Text: of the national heritage as paddlesteamers and

Speaker: NA
Text: even a Chinese joss house.

Speaker: NA
Text: A pleasing feature ofthe report is its rejection

Speaker: NA
Text: of the widely held notion that conservation and

Speaker: NA
Text: preservation of the environment are a 'middle

Speaker: NA
Text: class' issue. The Committee affirms this is just

Speaker: NA
Text: true and that preserving the National Estate con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerns us all. It shatters once and for all the

Speaker: NA
Text: illusion that the national estate is the preserve

Speaker: NA
Text: the better-off members of the community. The

Speaker: NA
Text: forces which threaten our National Estate often

Speaker: NA
Text: bear most heavily on the less privileged. Poorer

Speaker: NA
Text: people suffer more intensely from the loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: parkland, familiar city and country scapes, and

Speaker: NA
Text: even dwellings. Deprived commumty groups

Speaker: NA
Text: have not the same access as the wealthy to other

Speaker: NA
Text: sources of personal enjoyment and fulfilment.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is why it is often the less affluent who are

Speaker: NA
Text: most active in working to protect the best fea-

Speaker: NA
Text: tures of our heritage. That is why the trade union

Speaker: NA
Text: movement has been active in trying to protect

Speaker: NA
Text: and enhance our National Estate. The pillage

Speaker: NA
Text: and neglect of the National Estate diminishes us

Speaker: NA
Text: all in equal measure. I also want to make it plain

Speaker: NA
Text: that I seek the support of people of goodwill

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever their background in protecting the

Speaker: NA
Text: National Estate and passing it intact to future

Speaker: NA
Text: generations. We will work with all those who

Speaker: NA
Text: want to protect those parts of our heritage that

Speaker: NA
Text: have been created by man or nature and are

Speaker: NA
Text: unique or are things of beauty.

Speaker: NA
Text: I want to make it clear that the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has not been idle while it waited for the report

Speaker: NA
Text: the Committee of Inquiry. In the last financial

Speaker: NA
Text: year more than $2m was provided to help the

Speaker: NA
Text: State governments and other organisations prestrive

Speaker: NA
Text: serve the National Estate. In the Budget now

Speaker: NA
Text: fore the Parhament, for 1974-75, this has been

Speaker: NA
Text: lifted to $8m. We have also announced our

Speaker: NA
Text: intention to establish a National Heritage Comfirmly

Speaker: NA
Text: mission to administer our pohcy on the National

Speaker: NA
Text: Estate. This was one of the more important

Speaker: NA
Text: recommendations of the Committee. This Comment

Speaker: NA
Text: mission will be responsible to the Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Environment and Conservation and myself. We

Speaker: NA
Text: expect that legislation to set up the Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: will be put to the ParUament in this session

Speaker: NA
Text: early in 1975. In the meantime a 17 member ing

Speaker: NA
Text: interim committee has been set up to help bridge

Speaker: NA
Text: the gap between the Committee of Inquiry and

Speaker: NA
Text: the proposed Heritage Commission. The Comthe

Speaker: NA
Text: mittee is headed by Mr David Yencken who perand

Speaker: NA
Text: formed valuable services as a member of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee of Inquiry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer honourable members to the attention

Speaker: NA
Text: given by the report to the role of the AustraUan

Speaker: NA
Text: Government in fostering the national estate.

Speaker: NA
Text: number of new roles have been

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. The Committee's broad recom-

Speaker: NA
Text: not mendations cover land use planning, conser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vation and reservation techniques and the prin-

Speaker: NA
Text: ciples of national parks. They extend to the

Speaker: NA
Text: of impact of mining, forestry and coastal develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the national estate. Thereportalso pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: poses a nationalregisterof sites of historic and

Text: obstruct or hinder the transport of goods or the

Text: conveyance of passengers in trade or commerce

Speaker: NA
Text: with other countries or among the States. Again

Speaker: NA
Text: there are words in that Act which would seem to

Text: imply that the activities of the Seamens Union

Speaker: NA
Text: have been quite unlawful. Thirdly we have the

Speaker: NA
Text: Navigation Act which requires that seamen in-

Speaker: NA
Text: volved in the coastal trade be paid proper rates

Speaker: NA
Text: and not rates less than those normally paid to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australians operating in Australian ships. Sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions 288 and 289 of the Navigation Act spell out

Speaker: NA
Text: very clearly that every seaman employed on a

Speaker: NA
Text: ship engaged in any part of the coasting trade

Speaker: NA
Text: shall, subject to any lawful deductions, be en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titled to and shall be paid for the period during

Speaker: NA
Text: which the ship is so engaged, wages at the cur-

Speaker: NA
Text: rent rates ruling in Australia for seamen

Speaker: NA
Text: employed in that part of the coasting trade.

Speaker: NA
Text: Quite plainly, on the evidence that has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made available to the Ministers, the Seamens

Speaker: NA
Text: Union has said to the companies concerned that

Speaker: NA
Text: the money is going to come to it. The money is

Speaker: NA
Text: not going to go to the seamen concerned. The

Speaker: NA
Text: unions and Mr Elliott have exhibited utter

Speaker: NA
Text: callousness in relation to people on low rates of

Speaker: NA
Text: pay and they have conspired and extorted to

Speaker: NA
Text: make sure that those parts ofthe Navigation Act

Speaker: NA
Text: are in fact broken and not held. Therefore there

Speaker: NA
Text: were three possible courses of action that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Ministers jointly could have taken. They could

Speaker: NA
Text: have launched normal police action because of a

Speaker: NA
Text: violation of laws. Much of what the Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Labor has done has sought to put above the law

Speaker: NA
Text: certain militant unions-no t all, but certain ones

Speaker: NA
Text: which are most concerned to use their strength

Speaker: NA
Text: mercilessly against their own members and the

Speaker: NA
Text: people of Australia. By their failure to act in

Speaker: NA
Text: these particular instances, by their failure to up-

Speaker: NA
Text: hold the law as it stands, by their attempts to

Speaker: NA
Text: cover this matter with an inadequate inquiry-

Speaker: NA
Text: not inadequate because of the Commissioner but

Speaker: NA
Text: inadequate because of the terms of reference and

Speaker: NA
Text: because of the attitude of the Ministers and of

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government-th e two Ministers have done

Speaker: NA
Text: great harm to propriety in government. They

Speaker: NA
Text: have destroyed their own reputations, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly the Minister for Transport who clearly, on

Speaker: NA
Text: has the evidence available has been involved in these

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: more than 12 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: On this basis one would have hoped that the

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: take the course which I suggested at the outset.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no other way in which the Prime Minis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter can preserve integrity for his Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: This matter runs through and into the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments. It involves the two Ministers. They were

Speaker: NA
Text: given evidence. Laws are available. They have

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: law. If that is to happen and it is to increase con-

Speaker: NA
Text: trol of this government by people like Mr Elliott

Speaker: NA
Text: industrial anarchy will become rampant

Speaker: NA
Text: throughout the Australian community.

Text: An incident was brought to my attention on

Text: I refer to your telegram dated 9 August concerning

Text: 'Sloman Alstertor'. Prior to issuing permit for 'Sloman

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: You will be aware that the Navigation Act requires that

Speaker: NA
Text: seamen on ships licensed to engage in the coasting trade

Speaker: NA
Text: should be paid wages at the current rates ruling in Australia

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: 3 September 1974

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister for Labor and Immigration, Mr Cameron,

Speaker: NA
Text: today condemned the practice of maritime unions demand-

Speaker: NA
Text: payments to allow the movement of ships around the

Speaker: NA
Text: coast, and then paying the money into union

Speaker: NA
Text: funds rather than to the crew members ofthe ships involved.

Speaker: NA
Text: ' I consider this action highly improper and I am gravely

Speaker: NA
Text: my office on concerned,' Mr Cameron said.

Speaker: NA
Text: 'It is contrary to all union principles that anyone should

Speaker: NA
Text: from a worker any of the money due to him as

Speaker: NA
Text: wages. Organised labour has fought such practices for more

Speaker: NA
Text: that a than a century,' he said.

Speaker: NA
Text: "The gravity of the principle involved is not lessened by

Speaker: NA
Text: that in this case it is not employers, but unions, that

Speaker: NA
Text: in effect confiscating portion of other workers' earnings.'

Speaker: NA
Text: 'No self-respecting Australian unionist would want to

Speaker: NA
Text: from money gained in this way,' Mr Cameron said.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Cameron said that since he had received a complaint

Speaker: NA
Text: from the managing director of the Australian News Print

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr R. W. Henry, he had requested his depanment to

Speaker: NA
Text: the matter. He had also had discussions with the

Speaker: NA
Text: me-an d secretary ofthe ACTU, Mr H. J. Souter.

Speaker: NA
Text: These investigations had established that some maritime

Speaker: NA
Text: officials had immobilised the vessel 'Thunderbird' in

Speaker: NA
Text: on 2 August Sydney unions.

Speaker: NA
Text: until a sum of about $17,000 had been paid to the

Speaker: NA
Text: GRIEVANCE DEBATE

Speaker: NA
Text: 62 Care of the Aged-Proposed Fuel and Energy

Speaker: NA
Text: 52 Legislation in Western Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: - Question proposed:

Speaker: NA
Text: That grievances be noted.

Speaker: Mr WILSON
Text: Sturt) (12.25)-There is an

Speaker: NA
Text: aged care crisis in the community. There is an

Speaker: NA
Text: urgent need for something to be done in the aged

Speaker: NA
Text: care area. Many of the people in the community

Speaker: NA
Text: who are operating organisations concerned with

Speaker: NA
Text: care for the aged expected that in the Budget,

Speaker: NA
Text: there would be some recogmtion of their needs,

Speaker: NA
Text: Cameron, Donald

Speaker: NA
Text: Connolly, D. M.

Speaker: NA
Text: but they were disappointed. It is true that the

Speaker: NA
Text: supplementary benefit in respect of nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home care was increased on 1 August. But all

Speaker: NA
Text: Edwards, H. R.

Speaker: NA
Text: Erwin, G. D.

Speaker: NA
Text: that did was enable patients in nursing homes to

Speaker: NA
Text: afford the fees that then reflected the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: operating those nursing homes. My concern

Speaker: NA
Text: today is for the patients. Those patients are going

Speaker: NA
Text: from onefinancialcrisis to another because of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government's failure to recognise in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget the need to announce that nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits should be index related. A study of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Howard.J.W.

Speaker: NA
Text: Hunt, R. J.D.

Speaker: NA
Text: figures on nursing home fees since 1 August indi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cates quite clearly that, as a consequence of rising

Speaker: NA
Text: costs, fees are getting beyond the level that a

Speaker: NA
Text: pensioner can afford to pay for proper nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home care.

Speaker: NA
Text: Whenever one hears that nursing home fees

Speaker: NA
Text: have risen it is very easy to think that those who

Speaker: NA
Text: are operating the homes are putting up the fees

Speaker: NA
Text: in order to make a substantial profit. I draw the

Speaker: NA
Text: attention of the House to the fact that nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home fees are controUed. Nursing homes can

Speaker: NA
Text: raise their fees only if the increase is approved by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Department of Social Security. That Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: Peacock, A. S.

Speaker: NA
Text: Robinson, Eric

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has been examining many claims by nurs-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing home operators-som e private and some

Speaker: NA
Text: combined charity and benevolent organisations

Speaker: NA
Text: -t o justify increased fees and it has granted the

Speaker: NA
Text: increases because the fact is that over recent

Speaker: NA
Text: months the costs of operating nursing homes

Speaker: NA
Text: have escalated at a rate far in excess of the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer price index and there are still further

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in the pipeline.

Speaker: NA
Text: Many of the nursing homes run by charities

Speaker: NA
Text: and benevolent organisations were nearly bank-

Speaker: NA
Text: rupt in July. Because of their plight, the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment took temporary action. But aU it did was to

Speaker: NA
Text: release a tourniquet that had been tightening to

Speaker: NA
Text: strangulation point. The Government gave no

Speaker: NA
Text: indicauon of when nursing home fees would be

Speaker: NA
Text: again increased. Many nursing homes expected

Speaker: NA
Text: something to be done in the Budget. But if we

Speaker: NA
Text: look at the Budget we find that there is talk about

Speaker: NA
Text: deficit budgeting. If one studies the words and

Speaker: NA
Text: the papers attached to the Budget documents

Speaker: NA
Text: one will find that the Government expects to

Speaker: NA
Text: spend a mere $1.8m over and above thefigureit

Speaker: NA
Text: anticipated spending on 1 August when nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: home benefits were increased to bring them to a

Speaker: NA
Text: realistic level. It is quite clear that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment does not intend to increase nursing home

Speaker: NA
Text: benefits between now and August of next year. I

Speaker: NA
Text: challenge the Minister for Social Security ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Hayden) to deny that that is so. If he is able to

Speaker: NA
Text: deny that it is so, why did he not include in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Estimates contained in the Budget a provision

Speaker: NA
Text: for greater funding of nursing homes? The pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vision of a mere additional $1.8m in funds for

Speaker: NA
Text: nursing home care for the aged will go nowhere.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Minister has said that he wants to enable the

Speaker: NA
Text: charity and benevolent organisations which are

Speaker: NA
Text: operating nursing homes to provide greater

Speaker: NA
Text: facilities. It is not a question of their being able

Speaker: NA
Text: provide greater facihties; the crisis is that they

Speaker: NA
Text: will not be able to provide the facihties that they

Speaker: NA
Text: now offer to many thousands of needy people.

Speaker: NA
Text: He speaks about deficit budgeting as though the

Speaker: NA
Text: non-profit organisations are the only nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes that provide for pensioner patients. The

Speaker: NA
Text: facts is that 80 per cent of all patients in nursing

Speaker: NA
Text: homes are pensioners.

Speaker: NA
Text: The former Liberal-Country Party Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment set in motion machinery that was designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to update nursing home benefits so that a patient

Speaker: NA
Text: with a pension income could not only afford

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable accommodation but be left with

Speaker: NA
Text: some spending money equivalent to one-quarter

Speaker: NA
Text: of the standard rate pension plus supplementary

Speaker: NA
Text: assistance. What has this Government done? It

Speaker: NA
Text: has reduced the amount of spending money

Speaker: NA
Text: available to the pensioner from what it should be

Speaker: NA
Text: today-from $8.75 to $4. That $4 is now

Speaker: NA
Text: insufficient to cover the costs of the large number

Speaker: NA
Text: of nursing homes that are forced, because of

Speaker: NA
Text: wage claims, to charge fees in excess of what is

Speaker: NA
Text: commonly regarded as the standard fee- a fee

Speaker: NA
Text: calculated by adding the nursing home benefit

Speaker: NA

Text: This report on the prices of

Text: household soaps and detergents, which has just

Speaker: NA

Text: the Shorter Oxford English Dictionary is any

Text: Kingdom industry. I am disappointed that a per-

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: emotional effort spilling crocodile tears conincrease
