Text: an additional full time Deputy Chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Universities Commission. This wUl bring the

Speaker: NA
Text: membership of the Commission to eleven. At

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission has a full time Chair-

Speaker: NA
Text: man, Professor Karmel, and Deputy Chairman,

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Bull, and 8 part-time members. There

Speaker: NA
Text: are now 17 universities, and the WoUongong

Speaker: NA
Text: University College wUl achieve full university

Speaker: NA
Text: status in 1975. In addition the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: approved in principle the establishment of new

Speaker: NA
Text: universities at Albury/Wodonga, Campbelltown

Speaker: NA
Text: and Geelong. Members wUl be aware, through

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation which has been before this House,

Speaker: NA
Text: of the successive initiatives which the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has taken in relation to universities-th e

Speaker: NA
Text: abolition of fees and the assumption of full finan-

Speaker: NA
Text: cial responsibihty by the Austrahan Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment, provision for needy students, new and

Speaker: NA
Text: expanded medical schools, and support for new

Speaker: NA
Text: programs in social work, special education and

Speaker: NA
Text: community practice. Altogether the workload on

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission has increased markedly in re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent years and, given the major tasks of the

Speaker: NA
Text: universities in teaching and research, will not

Speaker: NA
Text: diminish in the years to come.

Speaker: NA
Text: Professor Karmel himself has been heavily

Speaker: NA
Text: engaged in a number of special inquiries, quite

Speaker: NA
Text: apart from his historic work with the Karmel

Speaker: NA
Text: Committee on Schools, and is at present bringing

Speaker: NA
Text: to a conclusion the report on open tertiary edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation. The Government has therefore decided

Speaker: NA
Text: that an additional Deputy Chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission should be appointed to assist with

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects of university programs which warrant

Speaker: NA
Text: special inquiry. He would have a particular re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsibihty for scientific developments and the

Speaker: NA
Text: estabUshment of new universities, and would

Speaker: NA
Text: provide high level representation for the Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission on committees concerned with these

Speaker: NA
Text: matters. The appointment would be at the same

Speaker: NA
Text: terms and conditions as for the present Deputy

Speaker: NA
Text: Chairman.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second main purpose of the BUl is to

Speaker: NA
Text: amend the definition of'university'

Speaker: NA
Text: pal Act to restrict the meaning of the word to

Speaker: NA
Text: institutions established by the AustraUan and

Speaker: NA
Text: State ParUaments. Some self styled 'universities',

Speaker: NA
Text: which are in fact private coaching or teaching

Speaker: NA
Text: ganisations, have been estabhshed from time

Speaker: NA
Text: time, some of them with questionable edugroup

Speaker: NA
Text: cational standards and offering degrees and

Speaker: NA
Text: awards of doubtful content. The proposed

Speaker: NA
Text: amendment places no restriction on the activities

Speaker: NA
Text: of such organisations but makes it clear that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission will not make recommendations in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of them; and this means they are not

Speaker: NA
Text: cepted as universities by the Government or the

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission. The BUl also includes 2 machinery

Speaker: NA
Text: measures. In accordance with the Government's

Speaker: NA
Text: practice, the word 'AustraUan' wUl be deleted

Speaker: NA
Text: from the Commission's title and it wiU become

Speaker: NA
Text: the Universities Commission. Provision has also

Speaker: NA
Text: been made for the remuneration of members of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Commission to be determined by the

Speaker: NA
Text: Remuneration Tribunal. I commend the BUl to should

Speaker: NA
Text: the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Adermann)

Speaker: NA
Text: adjourned.

Speaker: NA
Text: REMUNERATION TRIBUNALS BILL 1974

Speaker: NA
Text: BUl presented by Mr Lionel Bowen, and read

Speaker: NA
Text: afirsttime.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith-

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Mimster in Matters Relating to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service) (2.40)-I move:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: NA
Text: I present a BUl to be known as the Remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunals BUl 1974. This BUl, which wUl amend

Speaker: NA
Text: the Remuneration Tribunal Act 1973, has 4

Speaker: NA
Text: major purposes. First, the BUl expands the for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mal jurisdiction of the Remuneration Tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: beyond the limits set in the present Act, to give

Speaker: NA
Text: full effect to the Government's pohcy that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal should fix the remuneration for all

Speaker: NA
Text: senior public offices in the Australian Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment area. At present the Act provides for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal to determine the salaries of statutory

Speaker: NA
Text: office holders but does not give it power over

Speaker: NA
Text: many simUar positions which have in the past

Speaker: NA
Text: been dealt with by the same salary fixing pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedures as statutory office holders. Examples are

Speaker: NA
Text: the various offices which were included in the

Speaker: NA
Text: indicative determination which formed part of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tribunal's 1974 review. They included,

Speaker: NA
Text: amongst others, the General Manager of Qantas,

Speaker: NA
Text: the Chiefs of Staff and the heads of several

Speaker: NA
Text: interim bodies for wbich statutory provision was

Speaker: NA
Text: in the princito be made.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second, besides expanding the jurisdiction of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tribunal the Bill lists several groups with

Speaker: NA
Text: orwhich the Tribunal is not intended to deal as

Speaker: NA
Text: to they do not form a part of the higher salaries

Speaker: NA
Text: and their remuneration has been fixed by

Speaker: NA
Text: other procedures. These groups include, for

Speaker: NA
Text: instance, the Trade Commissioner Service,

Speaker: NA
Text: which ought not to be in the Tribunal's jurisdic-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion but which falls within it at present. Thirdly,

Speaker: NA
Text: the BUl clarifies a number of miscellaneous issues

Speaker: NA
Text: acwhich have so far arisen from the application of

Speaker: NA
Text: the principal Act. Finally, the BUl inserts a new

Speaker: NA
Text: part in the principal Act providing for the estab-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ushment of an academic salaries tribunal along

Speaker: NA
Text: the Unes announced by the Government in April.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Tribunal wiU have the power to determine

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries for universities and colleges of advanced

Speaker: NA
Text: education estabUshed by law in the Territories

Speaker: NA
Text: and wUl recommend the rates of salaries which

Speaker: NA
Text: be used as a basis for grants to the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: I turn now to the detaU of the BUl. Clause 6

Speaker: NA
Text: amends section 3 of the principal Act to expand

Speaker: NA
Text: and clarify the jurisdiction of the Remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal along the Unes I have described. It lists

Speaker: NA
Text: the various categories of pubUc office with which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tribunal is to be required to deal, in addition

Speaker: NA
Text: to offices in the First Division of the Pubhc Ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vice, under section 7 (3) of the principal Act. Be-

Speaker: NA
Text: sides setting out these categories the Bill makes

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for additional offices or appointments

Speaker: NA
Text: to be prescribed by regulations. Clause 6 goes on

Speaker: NA
Text: to list offices for which the Tribunal wul not have

Speaker: NA
Text: power to determine remuneration. In general

Speaker: NA
Text: these are less senior appointments. There is also

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for prescription by regulation of any

Speaker: NA
Text: other offices which should be excluded from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal's jurisdiction.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 7 amends section 4 of the principal Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: It relaxes the very stringent conditions governing

Speaker: NA
Text: eligibility for membership of the Remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal. As the Act stands at present, a person

Speaker: NA
Text: cannot be appointed to the Tribunal if he has at

Speaker: NA
Text: any time served in one of the offices within the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal's jurisdiction. The Bill provides that a

Speaker: NA
Text: person should be disqualified for membership

Speaker: NA
Text: only if he has served in a relevant office within

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous 7 years. Clause 7 also provides that

Speaker: NA
Text: a member of the Tribunal shall not be appointed

Speaker: NA
Text: as Chairman if he has in the past 7 years been a

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the full time staff of a university or

Speaker: NA
Text: college of advanced education. This provision is

Speaker: NA
Text: included because the Chairman of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Remuneration Tribunal will be constituted as the

Speaker: NA
Text: Academic Salaries Tribunal.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 8 amends section 6 of the principal

Speaker: NA
Text: which deals with judges and Ministers of State.

Speaker: NA
Text: Its purpose is to include with judges, persons

Speaker: NA
Text: who have the same status by virtue of an Act.

Speaker: NA
Text: This means that the Tribunal will report on the

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration of such persons rather than deterfor

Speaker: NA
Text: mine it. This provision has been introduced to the

Speaker: NA
Text: cover the case of the President and Deputy Presireport

Speaker: NA
Text: dents of the Conciliation and Arbitration Comin

Speaker: NA
Text: mission. There is no constitutional obstacle

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal having power to determine

Speaker: NA
Text: these people but it is desirable for the sake of

Speaker: NA
Text: consistency that they should be considered by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tribunal in conjunction with judges. Clause 8

Speaker: NA
Text: also revises the existing provision in section 6

Speaker: NA
Text: the principal Act dealing with matters 'sigsars

Speaker: NA
Text: nificantly related to remuneration'. It authorises

Speaker: NA
Text: the Tribunal to inquire into matters which are,

Speaker: NA
Text: which it considers to be, significantly related

Speaker: NA
Text: the remuneration of Ministers and judges either

Speaker: NA
Text: on its own initiative or at the request of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 9 amends section 7 of the principal

Speaker: NA
Text: which gives the Tribunal power to determine

Speaker: NA
Text: remuneration for parliamentarians, First Divitself

Speaker: NA
Text: ision officers and statutory office holders. It

Speaker: NA
Text: introduces a revised provision dealing with 'siging

Speaker: NA
Text: nificantly related' matters similar to that

Speaker: NA
Text: clause 8. It also provides that where

Speaker: NA
Text: funds available for the payment of remuneration

Speaker: NA
Text: they shall be used for this purpose. The principal

Speaker: NA
Text: Aa at present provides that remuneration in

Speaker: NA
Text: every case be paid from the Consolidated

Speaker: NA
Text: Revenue Fund and this is inconsistent with long

Speaker: NA
Text: standing arrangements for a number of com-

Speaker: NA
Text: pames and statutory corporations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 9 also provides that members of Parha-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment or candidates for election will not be en-

Speaker: NA
Text: titled to any remuneration for holding a pubhc

Speaker: NA
Text: office, that persons in the full-time service of

Speaker: NA
Text: Austraha will not receive payment for holding a

Speaker: NA
Text: parttimeoffice except as prescribed, and that the

Speaker: NA
Text: holders of judicial offices in the States and other

Speaker: NA
Text: countries will not receive remuneration except as

Speaker: NA
Text: prescribed. Clause 10 amends section 8 of the

Speaker: NA
Text: principal Act to make an exception from the

Speaker: NA
Text: general rule that the Tribunal must deal at the

Speaker: NA
Text: one time with all the offices in its jurisdiction. It

Speaker: NA
Text: provides for the Tribunal to make individual

Speaker: NA
Text: determinations for new offices and offices whose

Speaker: NA
Text: functions have substantially changed since the

Speaker: NA
Text: Tribunal last reported.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clause 11 amends the principal Aa by the

Speaker: NA
Text: insertion of a new Part estabhshing the Aca-

Speaker: NA
Text: demic Salaries Tribunal. As I said earlier the

Speaker: NA
Text: Academic Salaries Tribunal will be constituted

Speaker: NA
Text: Act by the chairman of the Remuneration Tribunal.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is provision for appointment of assessors.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Tribunal will deal with academic staff in

Speaker: NA
Text: universities and colleges of advanced education.

Speaker: NA
Text: As I indicated earlier it will determine salaries

Speaker: NA
Text: academic staff in institutions established by

Speaker: NA
Text: laws of Austraha in the Territories. It will also

Speaker: NA
Text: on the rates of salaries for academic staff

Speaker: NA
Text: other institutions of tertiary education and

Speaker: NA
Text: to the recommend the rates to be used for making

Speaker: NA
Text: salaries for grants to the States.

Speaker: NA
Text: Besides considering academic salaries, the Tri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bunal may report on the salaries of vice chancel-

Speaker: NA
Text: lors, principals, other chief executive officers, and

Speaker: NA
Text: of other senior officers such as registrars and bur-

Speaker: NA
Text: in universities and colleges of advanced edu-

Speaker: NA
Text: cation. The procedures relating to the Tribunal's

Speaker: NA
Text: or determinations will be the same as for the

Speaker: NA
Text: to Remuneration Tribunal. The Minister will ar-

Speaker: NA
Text: range for a copy of each determination to be laid

Speaker: NA
Text: before each House within 15 sitting days of re-

Speaker: NA
Text: ceipt by him and either House will be able to dis-

Speaker: NA
Text: Act allow any determination within 15 sitting days

Speaker: NA
Text: after a copy has been laid before it. The Tribunal

Speaker: NA
Text: will have power to decide when to make

Speaker: NA
Text: reports and determinations. The provisions relat-

Speaker: NA
Text: to methods of inquiry by the Tribunal are the

Speaker: NA
Text: in same as for the Remuneration Tribunal. I com-

Speaker: NA
Text: a body has mend the Bill to the House.

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate (on motion by Mr Adermann) ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: journed.

Speaker: NA
Text: POST AND TELEGRAPH RATES BILL

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 17 September (vide

Speaker: NA
Text: page 1437), on motion by Mr Lionel Bowen:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith-

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Minister of State)-Ma y I have the indul-

Speaker: NA
Text: gence of the House to raise a point of procedure

Speaker: NA
Text: on this legislation? Before the debate on this Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: is resumed I would like to suggest that it may suit

Speaker: NA
Text: the convenience of the House to have a general

Speaker: NA
Text: debate covering this Bill and the Post and Tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: graph Bill 1974 (No. 2) as they are related

Speaker: NA
Text: measures. Separate questions will, of course, be

Speaker: NA
Text: put on each of the Bills at the conclusion of the

Speaker: NA
Text: debate. I suggest therefore, Mr Speaker, that you

Speaker: NA
Text: permit the subject matter of both BiUs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: discussed in this debate.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: I s it the wish of the House to

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt this procedure? There being no objection,

Speaker: NA
Text: I will aUow that course to be followed.

Speaker: Mr NIXON
Text: Gippsland) (2.48)-The first

Speaker: NA
Text: tiling I want to do is to lodge a protest on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition that this very important Bud-

Speaker: NA
Text: get BUl should be introduced into the House for

Speaker: NA
Text: consideration in detaU by the Parhament before

Speaker: NA
Text: the Leader of the Opposition ( Mr Snedden) has

Speaker: NA
Text: had a chance to present to the ParUament his

Speaker: NA
Text: analysis of the Budget as a whole. It is an

Speaker: NA
Text: improper practice. I am quite sure that we could

Speaker: NA
Text: have facilitated the passage of this legislation,

Speaker: NA
Text: both through this House and the Senate, had the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government been prepared to co-operate. The

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation could have been passed through the

Speaker: NA
Text: House by the due date, 1 October. I understand

Speaker: NA
Text: that that is the point of time at which the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government wants to start collecting the exorbi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tant charges which are provided for under this

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation is of major importance to the

Speaker: NA
Text: AustraUan people. The Post Office, as an effec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive monopoly, provides services to the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity which affect the quality of Ufe of the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trahan people. What that in turn means is that

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in the prices of these services wUl have

Speaker: NA
Text: a major impact on both the rate of inflation and

Speaker: NA
Text: the people's awareness of the rate of inflation.

Speaker: NA
Text: The proposed increases are very substantial.

Speaker: NA
Text: They include an increase of 43 per cent in the

Speaker: NA
Text: basic postage rate, an increase of 33 per cent in

Speaker: NA
Text: the telephone service connection fee for new ap-

Speaker: NA
Text: pUcants, a 30 per cent increase in the local tele-

Speaker: NA
Text: phone caU fee, and an overall increase of 50 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in telegram charges. They are just a few

Speaker: NA
Text: (No.2) 1974 examples. These increases wUl have a direct

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading inflationary impact and, as their justification is

Speaker: NA
Text: not required before the Prices Justification Tri-

Speaker: NA
Text: bunal, it is the duty of this Parhament to

Speaker: NA
Text: scrutinise them carefully.

Speaker: NA
Text: A scrutiny of these charges must be looked at

Speaker: NA
Text: in the hght of approved broad criteria, including

Speaker: NA
Text: economic circumstances. It is therefore quite

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable that the Opposition should wish to

Speaker: NA
Text: wait for the presentation of the Budget before

Speaker: NA
Text: approving these proposals. I caU the attention of

Speaker: NA
Text: the House to the fact that on 23 July the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition opposed simUar measures both in this

Speaker: NA
Text: House and in the Senate. They were not these

Speaker: NA
Text: measures but lesser measures, I might say. We

Speaker: NA
Text: beUeved at that time that it was improper for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to introduce such measures prior to

Speaker: NA
Text: the introduction of its total Budget package. The

Speaker: NA
Text: postal services have run at a consistent loss since

Speaker: NA
Text: 1964-65. This loss is estimated in the Budget

Speaker: NA
Text: papers to increase from $21m in 1972-73 to

Speaker: NA
Text: $55m in both 1973-74 and 1974-75, even assum-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing that these increased charges will be put into

Speaker: NA
Text: effect. The Postmaster-General (Senator Bishop)

Speaker: NA
Text: estimates that if these increased charges are not

Speaker: NA
Text: approved the postal service wUl incur a loss in

Speaker: NA
Text: this financial year of $ 100m. This is no less than

Speaker: NA
Text: five times the loss of only 2 years ago.

Speaker: NA
Text: Because the postal service is labour intensive it

Speaker: NA
Text: is vulnerable to wage increases. The telecom-

Speaker: NA
Text: munications service, on the other hand, has a

Speaker: NA
Text: high capital content and is consistently and

Speaker: NA
Text: increasingly profitable. Clearly, the overall prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem rests with the postal service. From a study of

Speaker: NA
Text: the accounts it is quite clear that a very alarming

Speaker: NA
Text: deterioration is occurring in the financial con-

Speaker: NA
Text: dition of the Post Office. The Vernon Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission in April estimated that postal service ex-

Speaker: NA
Text: penses in 1974-75 would rise by 10 per cent on

Speaker: NA
Text: the 1973-74 level. Now, only 4 months later, we

Speaker: NA
Text: are told that the increase wUl not be 10 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: but a whacking 18 per cent, and this is in spite of

Speaker: NA
Text: severe restrictions on staff growth.

Speaker: NA
Text: This Parliament is clearly entitled to a detaUed

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation of this situation. I believe that the

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General has been derelict in his duty

Speaker: NA
Text: in that the second reading speech presented to

Speaker: NA
Text: this House by the Special Minister of State ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Lionel Bowen), who is at the table, says nothing

Speaker: NA
Text: on this point. In AprU the loss for postal services

Speaker: NA
Text: during 1974-75 was estimated at $65m. Now,

Speaker: NA
Text: with an increase in tariffs of the order of 43 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent for basic postal charges, this loss of $65m is

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced by a mere SlOm. One does not have to

Speaker: NA
Text: be a mathematical genius to draw a pretty fright-

Speaker: NA
Text: ening conclusion about the sorts of charges that

Speaker: NA
Text: would be necessary, in theory, on the basis of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister's assumption for that loss to be

Speaker: NA
Text: eliminated.

Speaker: NA
Text: Back in April the Vernon Commission thought

Speaker: NA
Text: that postal charges would need to increase at an

Speaker: NA
Text: average rate of 15 per cent. The Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: explained that this would mean that the cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: posting a letter would rise from 7c to 10c in less

Speaker: NA
Text: than 3 years. It has happened in less than 5

Speaker: NA
Text: months. The Parliament is entitled to an updated

Speaker: NA
Text: projection of postal charges in the light of the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: cent cost data. We are entided to a full expla-

Speaker: NA
Text: nation of the reasons for this deterioration.

Speaker: NA
Text: Clearly wages are rising, but one would have

Speaker: NA
Text: thought that productivity was rising also. What

Speaker: NA
Text: the Minister has failed to say is the extent to

Speaker: NA
Text: <^..which industrial disputation may be contributing

Speaker: NA
Text: .., to the problem. It should be a cause of national

Speaker: NA
Text: concern that the Vernon Commission reported

Speaker: NA
Text: that in the 6 months to June 1973 there were no

Speaker: NA
Text: less than 28 black bans imposed in the Sydney

Speaker: NA
Text: Mail Exchange; in other words, about one a

Speaker: NA
Text: week. Measured by articles handled per man

Speaker: NA
Text: hour, productivity at the Sydney Mail Exchange

Speaker: NA
Text: fell by about 10 per cent absolutely between

Speaker: NA
Text: 1964-65 and 1972-73. We are entitled to some

Speaker: NA
Text: explanation of what the Government intends to

Speaker: NA
Text: do about this. It is very simple to talk ofthe need

Speaker: NA
Text: to increase charges to meet expenses. It is even

Speaker: NA
Text: more simple, and probably misleading, for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Budget documents on the Post Office to say:

Speaker: NA
Text: The record demand for

Speaker: NA
Text: cates that the present level of charges for that

Speaker: NA
Text: tively low.

Speaker: NA
Text: There is no evidence to support that bald

Speaker: NA
Text: sertion. Indeed, there is no evidence to support

Speaker: NA
Text: the assertion of the Minister that these increased

Speaker: NA
Text: charges will yield the revenue

Speaker: NA
Text: Vernon Commission itself admitted that it would

Speaker: NA
Text: not be possible to calculate accurately the tariff

Speaker: NA
Text: increases necessary to offset trading losses,

Speaker: NA
Text: changes in tariffs affect demand. The crunch-i

Speaker: NA
Text: is a most important, indeed critical, crunch-i

Speaker: NA
Text: that we do not know and we are not told to what

Speaker: NA
Text: extent they affect demand. The Commission

Speaker: NA
Text: admitted that it was not able to work out

Speaker: NA
Text: elasticity of demand for postal services; yet

Speaker: NA
Text: are asked to approve increases of 40 per cent

Speaker: NA
Text: 50 per cent without any estimate by the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: of their impact on demand for postal services.

Speaker: NA
Text: Discussion over revenue and outlay really

Speaker: NA
Text: the question. The central issue is the Governsays,

Speaker: NA
Text: ment's economic philosophy and its social

Speaker: NA
Text: guidelines for the postal services. The Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: asserts that they must pay their way. The prob-

Speaker: NA
Text: lem is that we are never really told clearly why.

Speaker: NA
Text: One explanation is contained in the second read-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing speech, in which the Minister said:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government is not prepared to allocate more from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Budget to the Post Office because this could only be at the

Speaker: NA
Text: expense of our priority programs in the fields of education,

Speaker: NA
Text: welfare and health.

Speaker: NA
Text: Are we therefore to assume by this process of

Speaker: NA
Text: reasoning that it is more equitable in principle

Speaker: NA
Text: for low income earners to pay increases of 43 per

Speaker: NA
Text: cent in basic postage rates than it is for this pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: gram to be financed from the progressive tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation scale? The situation is even more puzzling

Speaker: NA
Text: when we are told by the Treasurer ( Mr Crean)

Speaker: NA

Text: town loaded with baggage cars, each totally

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: exchange because they can get service when they

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: the sosomething that unfortunately this Government

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to lack. The increases proposed wUl lead

Speaker: NA
Text: a 0.3 per cent increase in the cost price index. It

Speaker: NA
Text: his is not a very great percentage, but as I said

Text: earlier it will build up and will add to the grow-

Text: ing amount of inflation. If automatic wage inde-

Text: turn passes it on. What about the possible and

Text: and above indexation? It is unbelievable that the

Text: concerned with the Post Office for increased

Text: wages. I would say that a fairly large demand

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Text: plus which can be re-invested to help meet the

Text: that the new charges were based pardy on likely

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: over a period and carrying them at a much less

Speaker: NA
Text: cost to the pubhc in general

Text: The new ordinary letter rate of 9c, proposed in

Speaker: NA
Text: July, has been increased to 10c in this legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: I instance that in explanation of what the real

Speaker: NA
Text: situation is.

Speaker: NA
Text: The action of the Senate in July with respect to

Speaker: NA
Text: these charges is typical of how the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: has behaved, particularly since the last election.

Speaker: NA
Text: It operates somewhat as a government in exUe.

Speaker: NA

Text: those days not just by speakers from the Govern-

Text: fact by the national Press.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Some of the money problems that confront us

Text: would otherwise have been. It would be wrong,

Speaker: NA
Text: however, i f l were to let some of their remarks go

Speaker: NA
Text: without some form of reply. The honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Bowman made a most ihurninating

Speaker: NA
Text: remark. Whilst the Opposition was blamed for

Speaker: NA
Text: delaying postal increases for 4 weeks, he

Speaker: NA
Text: explained that the Postmaster-General himself

Speaker: NA
Text: delayed such increases for a period of 12 months.

Speaker: NA
Text: I invite the House to compare the amount of the

Speaker: NA
Text: proposed increases attributed to the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: for the delaying their imposition with the total

Speaker: NA
Text: amount involved. It is almost as much as that fpr

Speaker: NA
Text: which the Postmaster-General can be held re-

Speaker: NA
Text: sponsible for delaying the increases. So let us

Speaker: NA
Text: have no more nonsense about what the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition did or did not do. We are happy that we

Speaker: NA
Text: gave business people and other people a chance

Speaker: NA
Text: to get their houses in order and a lot of their work

Speaker: NA
Text: done in the certain knowledge that increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: various telecommunication and postal facility

Speaker: NA
Text: charges would be introduced in this Budget.

Speaker: NA
Text: Today the honourable member for Bowman

Speaker: NA
Text: complained bitterly about everything the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition did and then admitted that the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment also was to blame. The Government has a

Speaker: NA
Text: job to do and we do not oppose it on this

Speaker: NA
Text: occasion.

Speaker: NA
Text: It is only right that I should do as the honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Bowman did on behalf of his

Speaker: NA
Text: electorate, on behalf of Brisbane and perhaps on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of Queensland and make one or two com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments in relation to my own area. He said that at

Speaker: NA
Text: long last he feels that his electorate is getting a

Speaker: NA
Text: fair go with respect to telephone connections. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me instance a case with which I have been con-

Speaker: NA
Text: cerned and ask him whether his definition of a

Speaker: NA
Text: fair go applies. I have made representations on

Speaker: NA
Text: behalf of a young doctor who has been

Speaker: NA
Text: appointed to a modern hospital in Adelaide.

Speaker: NA
Text: Telephone cables passed through the end of his

Speaker: NA
Text: block which is 4 miles from the centre of the

Speaker: NA
Text: fairly major town of Murray Bridge. He applied

Speaker: NA
Text: for a telephone connection expecting to be char-

Speaker: NA
Text: ged between perhaps $200 and $400 for it. He

Speaker: NA
Text: was asked to pay $8,000 for the connection. I

Speaker: NA
Text: stress that his block was within 4 miles of Murray

Speaker: NA
Text: Bridge, telephone cables went through the end of

Speaker: NA
Text: it and within a few yards of his house. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bowman spoke of a fair

Speaker: NA
Text: deal for his people. He can hardly blame a Lib-

Speaker: NA
Text: eral member, not a Country Party member, for

Speaker: NA
Text: asking what is fair. There are people in my elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: torate which is comparatively close to Adelaide

Speaker: NA
Text: who are being asked for sums in excess of

Speaker: NA
Text: $ 10,000 for telephone connections.

Speaker: Mr JAMES
Text: The y have a quid too.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: I know that the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Hunter is a fair man so I ask him:

Speaker: NA
Text: What is fair? Is it not reasonable that a person

Speaker: NA
Text: who can catch public transport to work in the

Speaker: NA
Text: morning but who may choose to use his own ve-

Speaker: NA
Text: hicle should perhaps pay a share of the total cost

Speaker: NA
Text: of telephone facility installations? That is the sort

Speaker: NA
Text: of principle that was adopted in the past. The

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member for Bowman said that at

Speaker: NA
Text: long last he thought that people in his electorate

Speaker: NA
Text: seeking telephone connections were getting a fan-

Speaker: NA
Text: go. Perhaps I may comment on this aspect. South

Speaker: NA
Text: Austraha has been wonderfully well served by 2

Speaker: NA
Text: marveUous Directors of Posts and Telegraphs.

Speaker: NA
Text: The performance in South Austraha has been

Speaker: NA
Text: second to none but now, for the first time in my

Speaker: NA
Text: experience of the last 10 years, the fringe areas

Speaker: NA
Text: Adelaide are suffering. Switchboards do not

Speaker: NA
Text: have sufficient capacity and work has not kept up

Speaker: NA
Text: to programs. I think it reasonable to ask why. I

Speaker: NA
Text: am no expert on these matters and I was not hel-

Speaker: NA
Text: ped on this occasion by discovering from the Par-

Speaker: NA
Text: Uamentary Library that I could not get the Year

Speaker: NA
Text: Book for 1973-74. The last one I could get was

Speaker: NA
Text: presented in June 1973.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Keogh-Ther e is a shortage of labour.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: I do not know the reason but it

Speaker: NA
Text: makes life difficult for someone like me who

Speaker: NA
Text: wants to debate these measures. From the figures

Speaker: NA
Text: avaUable it is my understanding that the subven-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion from revenue for the Post Office in 1973-74

Speaker: NA
Text: was of the order of $385m. The subvention for

Speaker: NA
Text: 1974-75 is again $385m. To thesefiguresmust

Speaker: NA
Text: be added the internaUy generated funds of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Post Office as a whole. Then we must ask what

Speaker: NA
Text: performance we can expect from such allo-

Speaker: NA
Text: cations. I know that the present Government be-

Speaker: NA
Text: Ueves that users should pay for facUities. Ifindit

Speaker: NA
Text: hard to argue against that view. However, ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cording to the Treasury figures in the Budget,

Speaker: NA
Text: which is only 48 hours old, there wUl be an

Speaker: NA
Text: increase of 42.5 per cent in taxation receipts this

Speaker: NA
Text: year. Notwithstanding this fact, the Government

Speaker: NA
Text: has allowed no more to the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: General's Department this year. It seems to me

Speaker: NA
Text: that this is inequitable. Atfirstglance it appears

Speaker: NA
Text: that the Department has not been given a fair go.

Speaker: NA
Text: The whole Budget is based on the assumption

Speaker: NA
Text: that inflation will increase by slightly more than

Speaker: NA
Text: 20 per cent during the next 12 months. How can

Speaker: NA
Text: $385m plus internaUy generated funds produce

Speaker: NA
Text: the performance required? It is common knowl-

Speaker: NA
Text: edge from open discussion in my electorate in the

Speaker: NA
Text: fringe areas of Adelaide that one cannot get per-

Speaker: NA
Text: formance if one does not have the funds. I can

Speaker: NA
Text: understand the difficulties of the Department.

Speaker: NA
Text: This year there have been enormous increases in

Speaker: NA
Text: wage costs, and I do not object to them, but to

Speaker: NA
Text: have a situation where funds aUocated for this

Speaker: NA
Text: Department are the same as for last year seems

Speaker: NA
Text: to me to be letting down the entire system. Obvi-

Speaker: NA
Text: ously the performance cannot be as great as it

Speaker: NA
Text: was last year. People in country areas know very

Speaker: NA
Text: well what the Government is proposing and

Speaker: NA
Text: doing. Let us face it; the previous Government

Speaker: NA
Text: was culpable too. It was too good an idea for

Speaker: NA
Text: amount of revenue that the Post Office could at-

Speaker: NA
Text: tract into that area. This was well understood in

Speaker: NA
Text: country areas. But unless the extra amount which

Speaker: NA
Text: the Government has tacked on during the last 4

Speaker: NA
Text: weeks, and for which it has blamed us, is going to

Speaker: NA
Text: earn a lot more than any projection that one can

Speaker: NA
Text: of find in the Vernon report, we wiU not have the

Speaker: NA
Text: capital requirements to do the job effectively.

Speaker: NA
Text: That is really the only point I properly wanted to

Speaker: NA
Text: make. I hope that I am not wide in the facts that I

Speaker: NA
Text: have been able to glean but, as I say, I have not

Speaker: NA
Text: been able to get hold of what I imagine is the

Speaker: NA
Text: latest annual report from the Department. This

Speaker: NA
Text: has made it rather difficult for me to draw a

Speaker: NA
Text: proper comparison.

Speaker: NA
Text: The only other matter I wanted to discuss at all

Speaker: NA
Text: today arises from the remarks of the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member for Corio and the honourable member

Speaker: NA
Text: for Bowman. It has to do with what functions the

Speaker: NA
Text: Postmaster-General's Department should

Speaker: NA
Text: undertake and what functions it should not. We

Speaker: NA
Text: have already discussed- I hope we have done it

Speaker: NA
Text: properly-whethe r or not the Government has

Speaker: NA
Text: the funds to do the job and, if so, where they are

Speaker: NA
Text: to come from.

Speaker: NA
Text: The next point I wish to make is that if the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment were not so ambitious to protect its role

Speaker: NA
Text: in life I think more funds would be avaUable. Let

Speaker: NA
Text: me make one or two suggestions to the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. It is not the first time I have commented,

Speaker: NA
Text: for instance, on householder deliveries on behalf

Speaker: NA
Text: of various country newspapers in my area. I have

Speaker: NA
Text: been doing this on and off for some years. All

Speaker: NA
Text: country newspapers look on the competition they

Speaker: NA
Text: get from the Postmaster-General's Department

Speaker: NA
Text: as spoUing their competitive position entirely.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fromtimeimmemorial stores have advertised in

Speaker: NA
Text: the local newspaper. Chain stores rather altered

Speaker: NA
Text: the situation, but chain stores used to advertise in

Speaker: NA
Text: the local newspaper. With the advent of chain

Speaker: NA
Text: stores came the householder deUvery. Some

Speaker: NA
Text: people tended to use that system, which deprived

Speaker: NA
Text: provincial newspapers of a lot of their revenue. I

Speaker: NA
Text: just make the point in passing: Does the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment reaUy need to be in this role or could it save

Speaker: NA
Text: staffing if it were not involved in it? I do not

Speaker: NA
Text: know that I am interested in or that I wish to pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tect red telephones. They always seemed rather

Speaker: NA
Text: extraneous to me. But I presume that the need for

Speaker: NA
Text: red telephones has arisen because the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity does not think that the facUities are being

Speaker: NA
Text: supplied by the Post Office. By and large I think

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the public are prepared to pay i f

Speaker: NA
Text: they get an efficient service. I will touch on that

Speaker: NA
Text: matter again in a minute.

Speaker: NA
Text: We now have the intrusion of the Postmaster-

Speaker: NA
Text: the General's Department into the field of courier

Speaker: NA
Text: services. Why did they arise? They probably

Speaker: NA
Text: arose before the system of'Priority Paid' mail

Speaker: NA
Text: was introduced. Might I compliment the Depart-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment on the efficiency of the deliverytimesof

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Priority Paid' mail. I use that service quite con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistently. It cost me a great deal but it is a very

Speaker: NA
Text: efficient service and it takes a matter of hours for

Speaker: NA
Text: mail posted in South Australia to arrive here. I

Speaker: NA
Text: repeat that I do not think people mind paying

Speaker: NA
Text: when a matter of some urgency crops up if the

Speaker: NA
Text: service is efficient. I do not object to that, but

Speaker: NA
Text: do we now need sums of money available, wliich

Speaker: NA
Text: are specified in these documents, to set up a cour-

Speaker: NA
Text: ier service to be administered by the Post Office?

Speaker: NA
Text: My argument here, which touches on house-

Speaker: NA
Text: holder deliveries to a lesser extent, courier ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices and other similar services, is that surely

Speaker: NA
Text: payers' funds or loan funds can be saved if some

Speaker: NA
Text: of this side-th e fringe side, if you like-o f the

Speaker: NA
Text: service of the Post Office were retained in the pri-

Speaker: NA
Text: vate sector. If the private sector can do it and if

Speaker: NA
Text: people use it and if it costs the Department

Speaker: NA
Text: money to organise this, I do not think the tax-

Speaker: NA
Text: payer should be strained by providing facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: to set it up. That probably points up the deep

Speaker: NA
Text: philosophical difference between people on our

Speaker: NA
Text: side of the Parhament and people on the other

Speaker: NA
Text: side.

Speaker: NA
Text: I f l might get a httle tougher perhaps I would

Speaker: NA
Text: finish by saying that the honourable member for

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowman could not quite see the

Speaker: NA
Text: the honourable member for Bendigo ( Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Bourchier) when he touched on the matter of de-

Speaker: NA
Text: centralisation. I appreciate by the look on your

Speaker: NA
Text: face, Mr Deputy Speaker, that I have to

Speaker: NA
Text: within fairly close bounds when dealing with

Speaker: NA
Text: honourable member's remarks. Let us face it;

Speaker: NA
Text: just in my httle neck of the woods-i n my commetropoUtan

Speaker: NA
Text: paratively unimportant electorate, I suppose-

Speaker: NA
Text: this Government has already taxed the brandy

Speaker: NA
Text: industry out of existence, or very nearly so. It

Speaker: NA
Text: put up the price of petrol in country areas by

Speaker: NA
Text: ing away the country subsidy, resulting in

Speaker: NA
Text: increase of up to 27c a gallon in the Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory. The removal of taxation concessions

Speaker: NA
Text: has taken away the Uquidity of many farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: whose back many big country towns are founded

Speaker: NA
Text: today. So that affects the entire economy in

Speaker: NA
Text: towns Uke Murray Bridge, Renmark, OodGoverment

Speaker: NA
Text: nawoopwoop, or wherever else one may go.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Government has presided over the almost

Speaker: NA
Text: complete ruination of the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: This does not affect so much those people who

Speaker: NA
Text: are protected in the electorate of my friend from

Speaker: NA
Text: Bowman but it does affect the people who are in

Speaker: NA
Text: private business, whether that business be in

Speaker: NA
Text: main street or whether it be a rural one, in my

Speaker: NA
Text: sort of electorate. I wiU leave aside mentioning

Speaker: NA
Text: obvious things such as superphosphate, because

Speaker: NA
Text: the price has already increased from $ 15.50 a ton

Speaker: NA
Text: 4 months ago to $45.50 a ton now. I wUl leave

Speaker: NA
Text: that aside but wUl get to the fact that in my State,

Speaker: NA
Text: anyway, elected Labor Party senators and others

Speaker: NA
Text: in the State field are refusing to attend growers'

Speaker: NA
Text: meetings when they wish to register their pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: tests. Do not let us ever wonder why there is un-

Speaker: NA
Text: happiness with this Government in those areas.

Speaker: NA
Text: why It is very real, and people like me are trying to

Speaker: NA
Text: advise the growers not to strike and withhold

Speaker: NA
Text: goods from the city. Anyway, it would be coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: ter-productive. I think we are winning that fight.

Speaker: NA
Text: But they must be allowed the right to protest,

Speaker: NA
Text: and they wUl protest tremendously when every

Speaker: NA
Text: tax- country investment in a country town is hit by

Speaker: NA
Text: increased telephone charges or, if you like, petrol

Speaker: NA
Text: charges, because people in those areas use those

Speaker: NA
Text: facUities almost entirely for their job-t o earn

Speaker: NA
Text: their income.

Speaker: Mr JAMES
Text: Bu t they have other privileges.

Speaker: Mr GILES
Text: The y do not have the privilege of

Speaker: NA
Text: television in some cases. The do not have the

Speaker: NA
Text: provision of public transport. They do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: the provision of cheapness of commuting from

Speaker: NA
Text: one area to another, and in these areas the ma-

Speaker: NA
Text: jority of their costs of production is involved in

Speaker: NA
Text: point made by this sort of thing.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think probably one of the sUliest remarks I

Speaker: NA
Text: heard- I will not say who made it; it was made a

Speaker: NA
Text: keep little whUe ago-cam e from an honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: the member on the other side of the House who

Speaker: NA
Text: pointed to the importance of the telephone to a

Speaker: NA
Text: household. I do not deny that but,

Speaker: NA
Text: let us face it, if anyone asked me whether it was

Speaker: NA
Text: more important that Mrs Joe Blow should be

Speaker: NA
Text: has able to discuss why she and her neighbour lost 5c

Speaker: NA
Text: takat bridge the previous evening or the sorts of

Speaker: NA
Text: an costs that an industry has to meet in country

Speaker: NA
Text: areas to carry out its job under these new pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: visions that we are debating today, I would have

Speaker: NA
Text: on to say that there is no comparison. The honour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member for Bowman said that he was glad

Speaker: NA
Text: to see fairness of supply. AU we seek is that the

Speaker: NA
Text: in the future look at the fairness of all

Speaker: NA
Text: people in AustraUa, that it ensures that there is

Speaker: NA
Text: fair treatment for all of them instead of what

Speaker: NA
Text: seems to us to be a buUding up against one sec-

Speaker: NA
Text: economy. tion of the community at present.

Speaker: NA
Text: I hope that I have tried to be pleasant and

Speaker: NA
Text: the objective. I hope that thefiguresI have are not

Speaker: NA
Text: too far off the mark. If they are, I apologise, but it

Speaker: NA
Text: is due to the fact that the annual report of the De-

Speaker: NA
Text: partment has not been available from the Parha-

Speaker: NA
Text: mentary Library today for me to study the facts

Speaker: NA
Text: and figures as I would like to.

Speaker: Mr MORRIS
Text: Shortland) (4.25)-I will be

Speaker: NA
Text: brief in my remarks as the Special Minister of

Speaker: NA
Text: State ( Mr Lionel Bowen) has requested. The

Speaker: NA
Text: refusal of the Senate to ratify the proposed postal

Speaker: NA
Text: charges in July last can only be described at best

Speaker: NA
Text: as irresponsible and typical of the course of bull-

Speaker: NA
Text: headed obstructionism that has been pursued by

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposiuon in the Senate since December

Speaker: NA
Text: 1972. The Opposiuon has aptly been described

Speaker: NA
Text: as trying to operate as a government in exile in

Speaker: NA
Text: another place. The editorial of the Melbourne

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Age' of 1 August was appropriate when it said:

Speaker: NA
Text: Higher postal charges are not so much a part of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government's anti-inflationary program as a first step

Speaker: NA
Text: towards making the Post Office commercially

Speaker: NA
Text: viable . . . Significantly, the Opposition did not

Speaker: NA
Text: oppose the increased postal charges in the House of

Speaker: NA
Text: Representauves. Their rejection in the Senate must be seen

Speaker: NA
Text: as a tactical manoeuvre based on opportunism rather than a

Speaker: NA
Text: valid objection based on reason or pnnciple.

Speaker: NA
Text: At the time of the Senate's rejection last July of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Post and Telegraph Rates Bill of 1974, it was

Speaker: NA
Text: anticipated that if rates were not increased then

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Post Office could expect a loss of

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately $134m in 1974-75. Honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: members will recall that a few weeks later when

Speaker: NA
Text: the Prime Minister ( Mr Whidam) announced

Speaker: NA
Text: the deferment of the Government's child care

Speaker: NA
Text: proposals, the same Opposition set up a phoney

Speaker: NA
Text: outcry against this Government. The total cost of

Speaker: NA
Text: the child care program as promised in the elec-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion campaign of May last was almost equal to

Speaker: NA
Text: the loss anticipated to be incurred by the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: trahan Post Office. It would seem that the Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition's priorities then were that postal charges

Speaker: NA
Text: should be lowered at the expense of a total child

Speaker: NA
Text: care program because it cannot have it both

Speaker: NA
Text: ways. Whilst good arguments can be put forward

Speaker: NA
Text: that postal services ought to be considered as a

Speaker: NA
Text: social service on the one hand or as a straight

Speaker: NA
Text: business undertaking on the other, the reality is

Speaker: NA
Text: that both points of view are incompatible. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: reasonable that the user of services ought to bear

Speaker: NA
Text: the major share of the cost of providing the ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vices and not the general taxpayer. Hence there

Speaker: NA
Text: is a necessity for increased rates and charges.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Austrahan Post Office is the nation's lar-

Speaker: NA
Text: gest business operation. On average, in excess of

Speaker: NA
Text: 5,000 letters are distributed and more than 6,000

Speaker: NA
Text: telephone calls are completed every minute of

Speaker: NA
Text: every day. As such, the operation of the Post

Speaker: NA
Text: Office is a highly labour-intensive operation and

Speaker: NA
Text: depends much more on the willing co-operation

Speaker: NA
Text: of many people of differing skills and back-

Speaker: NA
Text: ground. Because about 70 per cent of its operat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing costs are expended on labour and as com-

Speaker: NA
Text: munity wage levels are rising, increasing costs

Speaker: NA
Text: are inevitable. Thefinancialdilemma facing the

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Post Office is not unique among the

Speaker: NA
Text: industrialised nations of the world. This is refer-

Speaker: NA
Text: red to by the Vernon Commission in its report on

Speaker: NA
Text: page 52. The problem in Australia has been that

Speaker: NA
Text: the Austrahan Post Office for far too long has

Speaker: NA
Text: been administered as a private political preserve

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Austrahan Country Party. It was managed

Speaker: NA
Text: in line with pohcies that were based on poUtical

Speaker: NA
Text: motives rather than on sound commercial prac-

Speaker: NA
Text: tice. One does not need to go beyond the highly

Speaker: NA
Text: expensive country telephone program initiated

Speaker: NA
Text: in 1970-71 tofindinstances where it would have

Speaker: NA
Text: been Uterally a better proposition for the Post

Speaker: NA
Text: Office to have bought the farm than to have

Speaker: NA
Text: incurred the cost of providing a telephone.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mention must be made also of the decision in

Speaker: NA
Text: 1971 to increase the Government's share of pen-

Speaker: NA
Text: sions and the decision of the Liberal-Country

Speaker: NA
Text: Party Government in 1972 to appoint Professor

Speaker: NA
Text: A. H. PoUard to inquire into methods of adjust-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Commonwealth superannuation benefits.

Speaker: NA
Text: Resulting from his recommendations was the

Speaker: NA
Text: Superannuation Act 1973.1 know that members

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Country Party are not interested. That is

Speaker: NA
Text: why they are leaving the chamber. The Superan-

Speaker: NA
Text: nuation Act 1973 provided for staff pensions to

Speaker: NA
Text: be adjusted by 1.4timesthe percentage increase

Speaker: NA
Text: in the consumer price index. These actions

Speaker: NA
Text: increased future payments to past and present

Speaker: NA
Text: Post Office employees. Accordingly there has

Speaker: NA
Text: had to be a sharp increase in Post Office pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments for superannuation liabUity. Post Office

Speaker: NA
Text: payments for superannuation Uability increased

Speaker: NA
Text: from $49m in 1972-73 to $104m in 1973-74, and

Speaker: NA
Text: provision for the payment of $130m has been

Speaker: NA
Text: made in the Post Office budget this year to meet

Speaker: NA
Text: the cost of this item.

Speaker: NA
Text: The present Opposition, when in Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: refused to initiate steps to place the Austrahan

Speaker: NA
Text: Post Office on a proper businesslike footing. It

Speaker: NA
Text: took a change in government to see the establish-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment of a commission of inquiry. (Quorum for-

Speaker: NA
Text: med). I thank the honourable member for Wan-

Speaker: NA
Text: non ( Mr Malcolm Fraser) for calhng some

Speaker: NA
Text: Country Party members to the House. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: interesting to note that it took a Liberal member

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition to call the quorum. Obviously

Speaker: NA
Text: he wanted some Country Party members present

Speaker: NA
Text: to particpate in the debate. I ought to remind the

Speaker: NA
Text: House that when post and telegraph rates were

Speaker: NA
Text: altered in 1973 the Country Party endorsed the

Speaker: NA
Text: increase in telephone rates. It was only interested

Speaker: NA
Text: in objecting to increased postal rates on country

Speaker: NA
Text: newspapers. It is not really concerned about

Speaker: NA
Text: increases in telephone rates. As I was saying, the

Text: Kingsford-Smith-

Speaker: NA
Text: But let us look at the rapid way in which

Text: CHILDREN'S COMMISSION

Text: Ministerial Statement

Speaker: Mr LIONEL BOWEN
Text: Kingsford-Smith-

Speaker: NA
Text: Special Minister of State)-Fo r the information

Speaker: NA
Text: of honourable members, I table a ministerial

Speaker: NA
Text: statement dated 19 September 1974 on the es-

Speaker: NA
Text: tabUshment ofa Children's Commission.

Speaker: NA
Text: PERSONAL EXPLANATION

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: Port Adelaide)- Mr Speaker, I

Speaker: NA
Text: wish to make a personal explanation.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Does the honourable gende-

Speaker: NA
Text: man claim to have been misrepresented?

Speaker: Mr YOUNG
Text: Yes , I do, Mr Speaker. I refer to

Speaker: NA
Text: the debate on the censure modon which took

Speaker: NA
Text: place in the House yesterday. As reported at

Speaker: NA
Text: page 1442 of yesterday's Hansard, the Leader of

Speaker: NA
Text: the Opposidon ( Mr Snedden) made the com-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment during the debate that he expected the

Speaker: NA
Text: Austrahan Council Bill to come before the House

Speaker: NA
Text: today. Being one of the speakers from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government side on the Austrahan Council Bill,

Speaker: NA
Text: I have been involved in discussions with people

Speaker: NA
Text: who have visited Parhament House in Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: this week concerning the sections of the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: which are causing some controversy outside this

Speaker: NA
Text: place. The Leader of the Opposition made the

Speaker: NA
Text: comment that information that had been given

Speaker: NA
Text: to the Opposition by me indicated that the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Council Bill would not come before the

Speaker: NA
Text: House. Mr Speaker, that is not correct. As I have

Speaker: NA
Text: said, I have held discussions concerning the Bill

Speaker: NA
Text: with people who visited Canberra. I did make

Speaker: NA
Text: inquiries as to when the Bill would come before

Speaker: NA
Text: the House. I did not at any stage talk to any

Speaker: NA
Text: member of the Opposition, includmg the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Opposition, about the make-up of the

Speaker: NA
Text: business that would come before the House. As

Speaker: NA
Text: all honourable members will understand, those

Speaker: NA
Text: of us who serve on the back benches do not have

Speaker: NA
Text: anything to do with deciding what business

Speaker: NA
Text: comes before the House. In that manner I was

Speaker: NA
Text: misrepresented in the House yesterday.

Speaker: NA
Text: WHEAT INDUSTRY STABILISATION

Speaker: NA
Text: Debate resumed from 17 July (vide page

Speaker: NA
Text: 294), on motion by Dr Patterson:

Speaker: NA
Text: That the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Dr PATTERSON
Text: Dawson-Minister for

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Development and Minister for the

Speaker: NA
Text: Northern Territory)- Mr Speaker, may I have

Speaker: NA
Text: the indulgence of the House to raise a point of

Speaker: NA
Text: procedure on this legislation? Before the debate

Speaker: NA
Text: is resumed on this Bill I would like to suggest that

Speaker: NA
Text: it may suit the convenience ofthe House to have

Speaker: NA
Text: a general debate covering this Bill, the Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Products Export Adjustment Bill and the Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Export Charge Bill as they are related measures.

Speaker: NA
Text: Separate questions will of course be put on each

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Bills at the conclusion of the debate. I sug-

Speaker: NA
Text: gest therefore, Mr Speaker, that you permit the

Speaker: NA
Text: subject matter of the 3 BiUs to be discussed in this

Speaker: NA
Text: debate.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Text: Is it the wish ofthe House to

Speaker: NA
Text: adopt this procedure? There being no objection,

Speaker: NA
Text: I wUl aUow that course to be foUowed.

Speaker: Mr SINCLAIR
Text: New England) (8.3)- Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker, the 3 BUls that we are considering to-

Speaker: NA
Text: night are BUls that politically are and have been

Speaker: NA
Text: traditionally the fundamental basis upon which

Speaker: NA
Text: many AustraUan farmers have been able to sur-

Speaker: NA
Text: vive the swing of the pendulum of seasons and

Speaker: NA
Text: the swing of the pendulum of markets. In the

Speaker: NA
Text: past the wheat seats, as they were called, were

Speaker: NA
Text: the seats that determined the fate of the govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment in this ParUament. Of course, these 3 BUls

Speaker: NA
Text: are radically different from the original stabUis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation proposals that were introduced into this

Speaker: NA
Text: ParUament. One wonders how Mr Reg Pollard, a

Speaker: NA
Text: former Minister for Commerce and Agricul-

Speaker: NA
Text: ture- a Labor member and one of those who

Speaker: NA
Text: originaUy introduced the wheat stabUisation

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation-might regard a BUl which goes by

Speaker: NA
Text: that pseudonym but which is, in fact, more a pay-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments equalisation measure than a stabUisation

Speaker: NA
Text: measure.

Speaker: NA
Text: Nonetheless, these 3 BUls encompass a range

Speaker: NA
Text: of assistance to the wheat growers of Australia

Speaker: NA
Text: which has resulted from discussions, if one can

Speaker: NA
Text: caU them that. They were discussions but they

Speaker: NA
Text: were conducted under a measure of duress with

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Wheat Growers Federation and

Speaker: NA
Text: with the members of the Austrahan Agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: CouncU. The proposals themselves are designed

Speaker: NA
Text: to provide assistance to those who will produce

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat during the next 5 years. As members of

Speaker: NA
Text: this place and wheat growers generaUy know,

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous S-year wheat stabUisation scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: BILL 1974 was extended for a period of one year. Over that

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading period the present Labor Government changed

Speaker: NA
Text: generally the character of the negotiations which

Speaker: NA
Text: I had entered into prior to the change of govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment and indeed changed the substance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: stabUisation proposals offered to the industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: I think it is appropriate that I deal first with the

Speaker: NA
Text: measures that the Government has brought for-

Speaker: NA
Text: ward, rather than the alternative proposals I

Speaker: NA
Text: would Uke to have seen developed. I think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: also appropriate at this stage to say that in the

Speaker: NA
Text: industry there has been quite real concern at the

Speaker: NA
Text: delay in debating this measure in this chamber. It

Speaker: NA
Text: is 3 months and 2 days today since the BUl was

Speaker: NA
Text: first introduced into the House. The Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: had hoped that the debate might have taken

Speaker: NA
Text: place during the July sitting. For various reasons

Speaker: NA
Text: this apparently did not meet the wishes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government. While the Minister for Northern

Speaker: NA
Text: Development and Minister for the Northern Ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ritory (Dr Patterson) said in his second reading

Speaker: NA
Text: speech that there was some delay because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: 18 May election, I think that it is equally true to

Speaker: NA
Text: say that it is unfortunate that there was not an

Speaker: NA
Text: opportunity for the measures to be debated in

Speaker: NA
Text: July and for wheatgrowers generally to be cer-

Speaker: NA
Text: tain ofthe result.

Speaker: NA
Text: However, I think there is some merit in having

Speaker: NA
Text: a look at the contrast between circumstances that

Speaker: NA
Text: prevail today and those that prevailed, not in

Speaker: NA
Text: July, but in the first of the intervening years be-

Speaker: NA
Text: tween the termination of the preceding stabilis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation scheme and the introduction of this one. Of

Speaker: NA
Text: course the significant change is that generally

Speaker: NA
Text: grain stocks around the world have dwindled

Speaker: NA
Text: mto negligible quantities. While in some coun-

Speaker: NA
Text: tries there has been a reasonable level of pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: duction -fo r example in the United States of

Speaker: NA
Text: America, which is still one of the world's largest

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat producers, there is this year a record

Speaker: NA
Text: crop-grain s today are more interchangeable

Speaker: NA
Text: than they have been. No longer do those who are

Speaker: NA
Text: in the market for wheat look at wheat as only a

Speaker: NA
Text: grain produced for human consumption; rather

Speaker: NA
Text: it is seen to a greater degree than perhaps it has

Speaker: NA
Text: been in the past as one of a range of grains

Speaker: NA
Text: produced either for human consumption or for

Speaker: NA
Text: stock feed purposes. In a blend availabUity of

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat alone is not the price determining factor,

Speaker: NA
Text: but its avaUabUity relative to the avaUabUity of

Speaker: NA
Text: other grains such as corn and nulo, and also

Speaker: NA
Text: other crops such as soya beans, all of which to a

Speaker: NA
Text: degree are interchangeable, and certainly all

Speaker: NA
Text: have a place for purposes of stock feeding,

Speaker: NA
Text: perhaps more than for human consumption.

Speaker: NA
Text: The legislation consists of 3 distinct BUls, the

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheat Industry StabUisation BUl, the Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Products Export Adjustment BiU and the Wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: Export Charge BiU. As I have suggested, the title

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Wheat Industry StabUisation BUl is a mis-

Speaker: NA
Text: nomer. As I see it, it would be far better called

Speaker: NA
Text: the Wheat Industry EquaUsation BUl. The Oppo-

Speaker: NA
Text: sition regards this as one ofthe more regrettable

Speaker: NA
Text: consequences ofthe changes which this Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment has introduced. In the present economic cU-

Speaker: NA
Text: mate for grains the wheat growers of Austraha

Speaker: NA
Text: wUl make a significant contribution to the con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumers throughout AustraUa which regrettably

Speaker: NA
Text: wUl not be recognised or wiU too rarely be recog-

Speaker: NA
Text: nised. In the past wheat growers have been pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared to accept a domestic price plan which has

Speaker: NA
Text: provided stabUity for the industry and they have

Speaker: NA
Text: taken their chance on the export returns. For the

Speaker: NA
Text: time being the current domestic price set within

Speaker: NA
Text: Austraha for home consumption is significantly

Speaker: NA
Text: lower than the world export price. The stabUis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation price set within this legislation is $2 per

Speaker: NA
Text: bushel. About a fortnight ago in the Kansas City

Speaker: NA
Text: Grain Exchange grain was bemg sold at US$4.61

Speaker: NA
Text: a bushel. That was a price which it was accepted

Speaker: NA
Text: might well not be avaUable at the low point of

Speaker: NA
Text: the season and indeed, it was significantly lower

Speaker: NA
Text: than some of the prices that had been offered

Speaker: NA
Text: some weeks before. So the price being paid

Speaker: NA
Text: domestically in AustraUa to Australian wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: growers under this arrangement wUl mean a sig-

Speaker: NA
Text: nificant contribution by. the wheat growers in

Speaker: NA
Text: respect of the 80,000-odd tonnes of wheat that is

Speaker: NA
Text: used within Australia for domestic purposes. It is

Speaker: NA
Text: being offered to consumers in this country at a

Speaker: NA
Text: significant discount but wheat growers accept

Speaker: NA
Text: that as part of the provisions of this stabUisation

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme as it has been in other schemes. It is a

Speaker: NA
Text: recogmtion by wheat growers that this predeter-

Speaker: NA
Text: mined price does give them a basis on which they

Speaker: NA
Text: can produce profitably. Therefore they are pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared also to produce greater quantities of wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: which supplements Australia's export earnings.

Speaker: NA
Text: Assistance is also given to the provision of those

Speaker: NA
Text: funds which are necessary tofinanceour national

Speaker: NA
Text: development and the achievement of national

Speaker: NA
Text: objectives which in the past have been set by the

Speaker: NA
Text: avaUabUity of funds but today seem to be set

Speaker: NA
Text: more by the ideology of the Government than

Speaker: NA
Text: the nation's capacity to pay.

Speaker: NA
Text: Within the provisions of the scheme those

Speaker: NA
Text: aspects to which I think reference needs to be

Speaker: NA
Text: made include the degree to which the stabUis-

Speaker: NA
Text: ation scheme itself has been changed as far as the

Speaker: NA
Text: owners-operators' allowance from the earUer

Speaker: NA
Text: scheme is concerned. There is a change in the

Speaker: NA
Text: basis by which industry and Government wUl

Speaker: NA
Text: contribute to the StabUisation Fund from which

Speaker: NA
Text: amounts are to be paid to wheat growers. There

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: basic wheat and in this respect the Opposition

Speaker: NA
Text: completely supports the proposal of the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment. The old 'fair average quaUty' terminology

Speaker: NA
Text: has been changed to 'Australian standard white'.

Speaker: NA
Text: There have also been changes in respect of some

Speaker: NA
Text: of the provisions related to unauthorised deal-

Speaker: NA
Text: ings with wheat which, of course, wUl be

Speaker: NA
Text: reflected in the complementary State legislation.

Speaker: NA
Text: These provisions are designed to minimise across

Speaker: NA
Text: the border trading particularly in respect of

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat that is being produced on leased land. The

Speaker: NA
Text: other aspect of change to which the Minister

Text: referred in his second reading speech and which

Speaker: NA
Text: has some importance, I believe, is the

Speaker: NA
Text: requirement of the Australian Wheat Board to

Text: tender an annual report on its operations. The

Text: Opposition completely supports that aspect too.

Speaker: NA
Text: The second of the 2 Bills- I will come back to

Speaker: NA
Text: deal with each of them in a htde more detail-i s

Speaker: NA
Text: termed the Wheat Products Export Adjustment

Speaker: NA
Text: Bill. This BUl really authorises the Board to

Text: require exporters of wheat products to pay to the

Text: Board the difference on those occasions when the

Text: export prices are higher than the domestic prices.

Speaker: NA

Text: against a disadvantage in export markets when

Speaker: NA
Text: export prices of wheat are lower than domestic

Speaker: NA
Text: prices, is prohibited from gaining an advantage

Speaker: NA
Text: in producing his product at a time when export

Speaker: NA
Text: prices are higher.

Speaker: NA
Text: This highlights one of the areas of deficiency

Speaker: NA
Text: this scheme, the faUure of the Government to

Speaker: NA
Text: realise some of the problems of the processors of

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat and wheat products. In the course of the

Speaker: NA
Text: last few months I have had some discussions with

Speaker: NA
Text: those who are in this category and each has

Speaker: NA
Text: expressed concern at the general impUcations of

Speaker: NA
Text: the provisions that the Government has brought

Speaker: NA
Text: forward and at the Government's faUure to con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sider the problems of avaUabUity of grain, the

Speaker: NA
Text: avaUabUity of grain of different classes and their

Speaker: NA
Text: abUity to compete in production of gluten or

Speaker: NA
Text: whatever the by-product might be with those

Text: who are producing that particular product either

Speaker: NA
Text: from other grains or in particularly advan-

Speaker: NA
Text: tageous geographic locations. For example,

Speaker: NA
Text: some advantage is given to an exporter of wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: products and a processor of wheat products who

Speaker: NA
Text: is now located in Tasmama. He gains through

Speaker: NA
Text: some of the provisions of this legislation from the

Speaker: NA
Text: equaUsation of wheat prices in that State an

Speaker: NA
Text: advantage over wheat processors on the

Speaker: NA
Text: mainland.

Speaker: NA
Text: The scheme set out in the Wheat Industry

Speaker: NA
Text: StabUization BUl is radically different from pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: vious StabUization schemes. It reflects generally

Speaker: NA
Text: the bias that this Government has against rural

Speaker: NA
Text: industries and which has never been better

Speaker: NA
Text: demonstrated than by the complete faUure of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Government to consider the problems of rural

Speaker: NA
Text: industries in the Budget presented on Tuesday

Speaker: NA
Text: night. Although the Government can claim that

Speaker: NA
Text: this wheat legislation was negotiated with and

Speaker: NA
Text: finally approved by the A u s t r a l i a n

Speaker: NA
Text: Wheatgrowers Federation, there is no doubt in

Speaker: NA
Text: the mind of every wheat grower in Austraha that

Speaker: NA
Text: it was a very unsatisfactory set of negotiations.

Speaker: NA
Text: As recendy as last weekend violent objections

Speaker: NA
Text: were lodged up in Moree in northern New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales to the imphcations of this type of legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation which for so many seems to capitahse on

Speaker: NA
Text: the presently advantageous world market con-

Speaker: NA
Text: ditions but prejudices the long term opportuni-

Speaker: NA
Text: ties for wheat production. I do not think it is

Speaker: NA
Text: unfair to say that the Wheatgrowers' Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: was bullied and cajoled generaUy with threats of

Speaker: NA
Text: intimidation and references to the Industries As-

Speaker: NA
Text: sistance Commission and all sorts of other

Speaker: NA
Text: alternatives to the point where it had no alterna-

Speaker: NA
Text: tive but to accept the proposals put to it by the

Speaker: NA
Text: AustraUan Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: SimUarly the objections raised by individual

Speaker: NA
Text: States were taken into account only to a minimal

Speaker: NA
Text: degree. It is unfortunate that the process of for-

Speaker: NA
Text: mulation of pohcy by this Government tends

Speaker: NA
Text: more and more to ignore the wishes of the

Speaker: NA
Text: individual and of the States but pursues a

Speaker: NA
Text: in philosophical bent which in the consequence I

Speaker: NA
Text: am afraid wUl lead to a marked disadvantage to

Speaker: NA
Text: the whole of our Austrahan community. The

Speaker: NA
Text: Federation, of course, was told to accept this pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: posal or there would be no StabUization scheme

Speaker: NA
Text: or that the scheme would have to go, if there was

Speaker: NA
Text: to be one at all, to the Industries Assistance Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission. With the traumas that many wheat

Speaker: NA
Text: growers have had over the last few years and

Speaker: NA
Text: with the problems which they now foresee in

Speaker: NA
Text: generally maintaining their profitability most

Speaker: NA
Text: wheat growers believed that they would just

Speaker: NA
Text: have to accept the scheme. It was for that reason

Speaker: NA
Text: and in spite of very real objections by some

Speaker: NA
Text: members of the Federation that the Federation

Speaker: NA
Text: finally accepted the proposals.

Speaker: NA
Text: SimUarly both Labor and non-labor govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments expressed their reservations at the Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian Agricultural CouncU about the manner in

Speaker: NA
Text: which the negotiations were carried out and on

Speaker: NA
Text: some aspects of the scheme itself. Many of these

Speaker: NA
Text: governments have approached members of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Opposition suggesting that we should move sub-

Speaker: NA
Text: stantive amendments to the proposals now be-

Speaker: NA
Text: fore us. It is very tempting for those of us who

Speaker: NA
Text: have a genuine interest and concern for pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: ducers to do so. But were we to do so, this being

Speaker: NA
Text: 19 September, we would be in a position where it

Speaker: NA
Text: would be impossible for those who are produc-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing wheat and wUl have it delivered to sUos

Speaker: NA
Text: within the next two or three weeks to know

Speaker: NA
Text: where they were going. Therefore we in the Op-

Speaker: NA
Text: position feel that we are being precluded from

Speaker: NA
Text: moving any substantive changes to this legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation. We are supporting this legislation not be-

Speaker: NA
Text: cause we believe it is good but because of the

Speaker: NA
Text: time factor and the lack of opportunity for us to

Speaker: NA
Text: change the legislation in a way that we believe

Speaker: NA
Text: would be desirable if the wheat growers, con-

Speaker: NA
Text: sumers and the interests of all Australia were to

Speaker: NA
Text: be taken properly into account.

Speaker: NA
Text: In many ways this scheme is quite inferior

Speaker: NA
Text: earher schemes It reduces the level of protection

Speaker: NA
Text: available to growers that was set out in former

Speaker: NA
Text: schemes. It reduces the level of government

Speaker: NA
Text: involvement in mamtaining the viabUity of productivity.

Speaker: NA
Text: AustraUa's major dry land farming industry.

Speaker: NA
Text: reduces the future potential of wheat growers to

Speaker: NA
Text: maintain their volume of production in the Ught

Speaker: NA
Text: of growing world food needs if world export

Speaker: NA
Text: prices should take a downturn. It faUs to

Speaker: NA
Text: nise the degree to which grain production is agriculture

Speaker: NA
Text: becoming more and more capital intensive. It

Speaker: NA
Text: faUs to recognise the necessity for the maintenvide

Speaker: NA
Text: ance of major agricultural industries in many of

Speaker: NA
Text: our outlying communities. Beyond aU that it still

Speaker: NA
Text: pursues a single commodity pohcy at a time represents

Speaker: NA
Text: when many other countries-th e United States,

Speaker: NA
Text: for example-ar e considering not just one grain

Speaker: NA
Text: but providing an opportunity for farmers to

Speaker: NA
Text: move from one source of production to another

Speaker: NA
Text: according to the potential profitabiUty to the

Speaker: NA
Text: ducer of those crops and giving him the same
