Text: protection.

Speaker: NA
Text: Let me advert for a moment to an aspect

Speaker: NA
Text: which it had been my intention to discuss with

Speaker: NA
Text: primary producers when we were in government.

Speaker: NA
Text: We were pursuing the idea of giving those who

Speaker: NA
Text: were in wheat production an opportunity to proare

Speaker: NA
Text: duce nulo or any other agricultural crop if

Speaker: NA
Text: crop were to produce for them a better result.

Speaker: NA
Text: wanted to see whether it was not possible to give

Speaker: NA
Text: them the same sort of guarantees as are provided

Speaker: NA
Text: for them in the wheat agreement. For example,

Speaker: NA
Text: many can produce oats, barley or milo. If one

Speaker: NA
Text: in a summer rainfaU area and there is a drought

Speaker: NA
Text: during the winter months it is far better

Speaker: NA
Text: duce milo than to leave the land faUow and

Speaker: NA
Text: duce no grain until the foUowing year.

Speaker: NA
Text: I refer those who might be interested in

Speaker: NA
Text: topic to a piece of legislation which the United

Speaker: NA
Text: States has on its statute book. It is pubhc

Speaker: NA
Text: 93-86 of the 93rd Congress. It was passed on

Speaker: NA
Text: August 1973. It covers not just a wlieat program

Speaker: NA
Text: but a program relating to a range of agricultural

Speaker: NA
Text: industries. The aspect I refer to the House in relaindustry

Speaker: NA
Text: tion to this concern which I have with this

Speaker: NA
Text: lation is that it is designed to attract the farm

Speaker: NA
Text: duction needed to meet domestic and foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: demand for food andfibre.The United States

Speaker: NA
Text: legislation accomplishes this by creating a

Speaker: NA
Text: favourable climate within wliich farmers

Speaker: NA
Text: respond to market signals which indicate

Speaker: NA
Text: sumer demand and thus produce the crops which

Speaker: NA
Text: are needed at home and abroad. This Act protake place.

Speaker: NA
Text: vides a concept of guaranteed or target prices. It

Speaker: NA
Text: has deficiency payments for a range of commodiIt

Speaker: NA
Text: ties. The deficiency payments are to be related

Speaker: NA
Text: to an average market price. They are related to that

Speaker: NA
Text: average market price remaining above a target

Speaker: NA
Text: level. The Act provides a bonus for individual

Speaker: NA
Text: productivity greater than the overall national

Speaker: NA
Text: In other words, it provides an op-

Speaker: NA
Text: It portunity for producer freedom and market

Speaker: NA
Text: orientated farm poUcy. To my mind this is a basis

Speaker: NA
Text: from which we in AustraUa might weU be able to

Speaker: NA
Text: encourage farm diversification which has been of

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: I support the Wheat Industry Stabilisation Bill

Text: of the uncertainty in the minds of wheat growers

Text: industry. These measures should meet with the

Text: approval of the industry. When introducing

Text: security against price fluctuations. The legis-

Text: bushel. This is an advance on the present legis-

Speaker: NA
Text: terday the FamUy Welfare Bureau in New South

Speaker: NA
Text: Wales had its annual meeting and closed its

Text: doors. I regard the closing down of the Bureau,

Speaker: NA
Text: voluntary social welfare organisation in New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, as a national disgrace. This organ-

Speaker: NA
Text: isation functioned in New South Wales after its

Speaker: NA
Text: formation during the last war. It was formed to

Speaker: NA
Text: provide welfare for ex-servicemen and their de-

Speaker: NA
Text: pendants. After the war its objectives and func-

Speaker: NA
Text: tions changed. It operated in Sydney in the area

Speaker: NA
Text: of Surry HUls, with a branch office in my elector-

Speaker: NA
Text: ate of Parramatta, with a number of valuable

Speaker: NA
Text: social workers. It performed invaluable tasks

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading that were respected by the people able to use the

Speaker: NA
Text: facUities it offered and who were able to be

Speaker: NA
Text: attended by its social workers. Now all the social

Speaker: NA
Text: workers have been dismissed. There are 2 people

Text: remaining on the staff until the end of September

Speaker: NA
Text: to deal with the remaining administrative mat-

Speaker: NA
Text: ters concerning this organisation. It operated in

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading the areas of Surry HUls and Parramatta and

Speaker: NA
Text: advised on matters of marriage guidance and

Speaker: NA
Text: matters relating to immigrants. It had a number

Speaker: NA
Text: of special projects of an intimate nature, includ-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a special study of migrants in car plants and

Speaker: NA
Text: their work in those plants. It also was undertak-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing a special study in relation to child care in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading Surry HUls area. Numbers of students, particu-

Speaker: NA
Text: larly those in the social work departments of the

Speaker: NA
Text: University of Sydney and the University of New

Speaker: NA
Text: South Wales, undertook practical training with

Speaker: NA
Text: this organisation and gained a great deal of

Speaker: NA
Text: benefit from it. It was the only remaining non-

Speaker: NA
Text: sectarian private voluntary organisation in this

Speaker: NA
Text: field in Sydney, and it has closed its doors.

Speaker: NA
Text: Second Reading

Speaker: NA
Text: I have a short table that I have copied out of

Text: the report on the income and expenditure of this

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: expenditure was $57,161. It had a deficit of $490.

Speaker: NA
Text: Third Reading For the last financial year, 1973-74, its income

Speaker: NA
Text: was $62,487 and its expenditure was $65,155. It

Speaker: NA
Text: suffered a deficit of $2,668. It was envisaged that

Speaker: NA
Text: in thisfinancialyear, 1974-75, on its budget its

Text: income still would be in the area of $60,000 but

Speaker: NA
Text: its expenditure would rise to $76,000. In these

Speaker: NA
Text: circumstances this organisation felt that it could

Speaker: NA
Text: no longer continue.

Speaker: NA
Text: through an electoral office in order to try to save one's politi-

Speaker: NA
Text: cal hide?

Speaker: Mr WENTWORTH
Text: Mackellar) (10.59)- I

Speaker: NA
Text: would not have risen to speak except for an inci-

Speaker: NA
Text: dent in the House today which I think I should

Speaker: NA
Text: draw to your attention, Mr Speaker. I spoke on

Speaker: NA
Text: the postal legislation and I informed the Leader

Speaker: NA
Text: be of the House ( Mr Daly) that I intended to speak

Speaker: NA
Text: for only 10 minutes. I did speak for longer than

Speaker: NA
Text: that but that was because I was interrupted from

Speaker: NA
Text: time to time with points of order, etc. A few mo-

Speaker: NA
Text: ments ago the Leader of the House said to me:

Speaker: NA
Text: 'Look, you spoke for 15 minutes before those

Speaker: NA
Text: points of order arose'. That was untrue and Han-

Speaker: NA
Text: sard will show it to be untrue.

Text: Order! It being 11 o'clock the

Speaker: NA
Text: House stands adjourned until Tuesday next at

Speaker: NA
Text: 10.30 a.m. or until such time thereafter as Mr

Speaker: NA
Text: Speaker takes the Chair.

Speaker: NA
Text: House adjourned at 11 p.m.

Speaker: NA
Text: The following answers to questions

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Capital Territory: Land Leases

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Hunt asked the Minister for the Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory, upon notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) How many blocks in the (a) restricted and (b) unre-

Speaker: NA
Text: stricted categories were offered for sale by his Department in

Speaker: NA
Text: the Australian Capital Territory during 1973-74.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) How many blocks were made

Speaker: NA
Text: houses, (b) detached housing and (c) flats during 1973-74.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Does this answer vary from that given on 31 August Brighton

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Was this quantity sufficient to meet expected popu-

Speaker: NA
Text: lation growth in the 12 months period.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as foUows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Aucdons of residential leases were suspended by my

Speaker: NA
Text: predecessor in August 1973. One auction was held between 1 Ripponlea

Speaker: NA
Text: July 1973 and the date auctions were suspended. Two hun-

Speaker: NA
Text: dred and forty one leases for detached housing were offered

Speaker: NA
Text: at that sale, 98 in the 'restricted

Speaker: NA
Text: B' and 99 in 'groups'.

Speaker: NA
Text: Between October 1973 and 30 June 1974, 1685 ofthe

Speaker: NA
Text: people registered for land under the new

Speaker: NA
Text: been offered residential leases. Of these 1160 have since

Speaker: NA
Text: been granted a lease or are in the process of taking up a

Speaker: NA
Text: lease, the remainder have declined to take up the offer. A

Speaker: NA
Text: further 1189 leases have been either sold or offered to freeBallan

Speaker: NA
Text: lance builders through a quota arrangement.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Under the Nauonal Capital Development Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission's land development programme for 1973-74, the

Speaker: NA
Text: following numbers of sites were available for lease:

Speaker: NA
Text: (a) 175 town house sites on which about 331 town house Meredith

Speaker: NA
Text: units can be built.

Speaker: NA
Text: (b) 3372 sites for detached housing.

Speaker: NA
Text: (c) 13 sites for residential fiats on which about 462

Speaker: NA
Text: residential units can be built.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) There is no record of an answer given on 31 August

Speaker: NA
Text: 1973. However, if the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: answer given to question No. 247 on 11 September 1973,

Speaker: NA
Text: then there has been a decrease in the numbers of sites

Speaker: NA
Text: expected to be available.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Leases sold during 1973-74 provide for expected

Speaker: NA
Text: population in 1974-75. The Nauonal Capital Development

Speaker: NA
Text: Commission has advised that it expects that the land made

Speaker: NA
Text: available together with land provided for Government

Speaker: NA
Text: owned rental housing is sufficient to provide for the

Speaker: NA
Text: estimated population increase in the current financial year.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Servicemen: Foreign Awards

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 507)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Wentworth asked the Prime Minister,

Speaker: NA
Text: upon notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Is it a fact that in previous wars, including Korea, Aus-

Speaker: NA
Text: tralian servicemen have been given permission to accept and

Speaker: NA
Text: wear foreign awards for gallantry.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Is it also a fact that, prior to going out of office, the pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: prepared a submission in relation to the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam war recommending that Australian servicemen be

Speaker: NA
Text: permitted to accept and wear up to four foreign awards in ac-

Speaker: NA
Text: cordance with normal practice of the Armed Services of the

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Did Austrahan servicemen in Vietnam gain 416

Speaker: NA
Text: United States awards and 604 Vietnamese awards; if so,

Speaker: NA
Text: what are the details.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Did Senator Bishop, acting on behalf of the Minister

Speaker: NA
Text: for Defence, intimate in December 1973 that Australian ser-

Speaker: NA
Text: vicemen would not be permitted to accept or wear foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: awards in relation to the Vietnam war.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) If so, was this a break with accepted custom due to a

Speaker: NA
Text: desire to downgrade all servicemen who took pan in the

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam war.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Yes. Foreign awards may only be accepted and worn

Speaker: NA
Text: with the permission of the sovereign. In previous wars, per-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission to wear gallantry awards of certain countries has

Speaker: NA
Text: been given in parucular circumstances.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) The right honourable member for Lowe, when Prime

Speaker: NA
Text: Minister, advised me in 1972 that a proposal was being pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: pared for the institution of Australian regulations relating to

Speaker: NA
Text: the acceptance and wearing of foreign awards (Hansard, 26

Speaker: NA
Text: October 1972, page 3437). I understand that the matter was

Speaker: NA
Text: not proceeded with. The wearing of up to four foreign

Speaker: NA
Text: awards is not a normal pracuce of the Armed Services.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) We do not have reliable information on the number

Speaker: NA
Text: of foreign awards proposed for Australian servicemen in

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam, as not every case was officially notified. The

Speaker: NA
Text: numbers of confirmed awards ran into some 250 Vietnamese

Speaker: NA
Text: and 200 United States awards.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) No. The Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

Speaker: NA
Text: said in December 1973 that there is no possibility of provid-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing additional awards, either British or foreign, for service in

Speaker: NA
Text: Vietnam. Approvals previously given for acceptance of the

Speaker: NA
Text: Campaign Medal issued by the South Vietnam Government,

Speaker: NA
Text: and of several foreign unit awards, still stand.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) See answer to (4). The policy on the acceptance and

Speaker: NA
Text: wearing of foreign awards for service during the Vietnam

Speaker: NA
Text: war was the responsibility of the Government in office at the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service: Coombs Report

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Snedden asked the Prime Mimster upon question

Speaker: NA
Text: notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) When did the Government receive the report from the

Speaker: NA
Text: Public Service Board of its inquiry into action being taken

Speaker: NA
Text: Departments to ensure that manpower savings are achieved

Speaker: NA
Text: in the implementation of recommendations

Speaker: NA
Text: Report and that staff involved are transferred to priority

Speaker: NA
Text: areas of the administration.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Has the Government considered the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Is it in the nature of an interim report to be followed up

Speaker: NA
Text: by subsequent reports.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) What is the Government's attitude to the report.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) When will the report be tabled.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: Th e answer to the right honourtheFurther

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The Chairman of the Public Service Board

Speaker: NA
Text: this matter on 29 November 1973.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Yes.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) and (4) The Government has not asked the Board to

Speaker: NA
Text: submit further reports specifically

Speaker: NA
Text: Board considers further such reports are necessary, it will no manent holding

Speaker: NA
Text: doubt provide them.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) As I told the right honourable member on 13

Speaker: NA
Text: December 1973 (Hansard, page 4821), the substance

Speaker: NA
Text: Board's report will be included in the Board's Annual

Speaker: NA
Text: Report for 1973-74. I expect to table the Board's Annual

Speaker: NA
Text: Report in September.

Speaker: NA
Text: Fire Fighting Procedures

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Snedden asked the Prime Mimster, upon

Speaker: NA
Text: notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) How often are exercises in civil defence preparedness

Speaker: NA
Text: conducted in Departments, for example, in evacuation pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: cedures of office buildings in the event of fire.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What form do the exercises take.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Does he accept that this is an area where the Govern-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment should give a lead to other employers.

Speaker: Mr WHITLAM
Text: Th e answer to therighthonour-

Speaker: NA
Text: able member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) and (2) The form and frequency of any exercises held

Speaker: NA
Text: in Australian Government Departments for the purpose of

Speaker: NA
Text: safeguarding life and property in the event of fire or civil

Speaker: NA
Text: emergency are as determined by the individual Departments

Speaker: NA
Text: themselves, with whom final responsibility for such pre-

Speaker: NA
Text: cautions rests.

Speaker: NA
Text: In determining the procedures to be adopted to cope with

Speaker: NA
Text: these contingencies Departments have expert technical

Speaker: NA
Text: advice available to them on request from the Australian

Speaker: NA
Text: Board in respect of fire protection and prevention and from

Speaker: NA
Text: the Natural Disasters Organisation in respect of civil emerg-

Speaker: NA
Text: encies whether arising from fire, earthquake,flood,building

Speaker: NA
Text: collapse or other hazard. The Department of Services and

Speaker: NA
Text: Property is also concerned with the property management

Speaker: NA
Text: aspect of fire prevention facilides.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The Australian Govemment has taken a leading role

Speaker: NA
Text: in preparedness for civil emergencies by the establishment of

Speaker: NA
Text: a Natural Disasters Organisation which will provide an ad-

Speaker: NA
Text: equate organisation to deal with natural disasters at a

Speaker: NA
Text: national level and, in consultation with the States, will assist

Speaker: NA
Text: in the strengthening of their capacity to cope with emerg-

Speaker: NA
Text: encies.

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 543)

Speaker: NA
Text: It will be recalled that I have a long-held interest in the

Speaker: NA
Text: of procedures and equipment for fighting and

Speaker: NA
Text: preventing fires in Australian Government establishments.

Speaker: NA
Text: Arising out of my Question on the matter (Hansard, 19 Sep-

Speaker: NA
Text: tember 1968, page 1357) the Australian Fire Board and the

Speaker: NA
Text: by Department of Transport are now studying developments in

Speaker: NA
Text: regard to standardisation of equipment and the question ofa

Speaker: NA
Text: of the Coombs Fire Training Institute.

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Kingston: Proposed Multi-storey Flat Project Services

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Garland asked the Minister for the Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory, upon notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Is the proposed multi-storeyflatprojea in Kingston by

Speaker: NA
Text: Hooker Home Units Pty Ltd now in doubt.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If so, is the reason because ofthe Government's policy

Speaker: NA
Text: of rent evaluadon and/or value added tax on re-develop-

Speaker: NA
Text: ment projects.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) Does the Govemment consider that this projea is

Speaker: NA
Text: desirable and the additional accommodation it would pro-

Speaker: NA
Text: vide likely to help alleviate the shortage of accommodation

Speaker: NA
Text: in Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Will he review existing policies with a view to encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: aging provision of accommodation in Canberra.

Speaker: NA
Text: (5) Is the present situation

Speaker: NA
Text: modation Canberra has ever known.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) Is it pan of existing policy for the Government to take

Speaker: NA
Text: over this land concerned; if so, is this likely to be the pattern

Speaker: NA
Text: in future.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (I) and (2) Approval has been given to a scheme of

Speaker: NA
Text: development subject to certain conditions. As far as I am

Speaker: NA
Text: aware the company has not yet reached a decision in the

Speaker: NA
Text: matter.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The project is in accordance with a decision made by

Speaker: NA
Text: the previous Government to permit but not actively encour-

Speaker: NA
Text: age redevelopment in Kingston. It would provide additional

Speaker: NA
Text: accommodauon but this could equally well be provided on

Speaker: NA
Text: other sites recently offered for lease for medium density

Speaker: NA
Text: housing in which limited or no interest has been shown by

Speaker: NA
Text: private developers.

Speaker: NA
Text: (4) Policies are continually under review. Under present

Speaker: NA
Text: arrangements leases for all forms of residential development

Speaker: NA
Text: are available at very reasonable prices.

Speaker: NA
Text: (6) The Government has no current plans to acquire

Speaker: NA
Text: residential land in Kingston or other pans of Canberra

Speaker: NA
Text: purely for redevelopment purposes.

Speaker: NA
Text: Carnarvon-Space Tracking Station

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Street asked the Minister for Manufactur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Industry, upon notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: What are the Government's plans for the future of the

Speaker: NA
Text: space tracking station at Carnarvon, Western Australia.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Enderby-Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as foUows:

Speaker: NA
Text: The present plan for operational work at Carnarvon is to

Speaker: NA
Text: continue the phasing out of activities, which as announced in

Speaker: NA
Text: February 1973 began early this year. By 5 October 1974 the

Speaker: NA
Text: tracking staff will have been reduced to one team and the

Speaker: NA
Text: total staff, currently a little less than

Speaker: NA
Text: reduced to about SO. The single team will be retained until

Speaker: NA
Text: 22 December 1974 or the launch of Helios, whichever is the

Speaker: NA
Text: sooner.

Speaker: NA
Text: Tracking and data handling equipment is being removed

Speaker: NA
Text: concurrently with the phase-down of operations and most of

Speaker: NA
Text: it is being reallocated to other NASA stations.

Speaker: NA
Text: The buildings and service facilities will be almost

Speaker: NA
Text: available to the Australian Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: and Property which will be responsible for the re-

Speaker: NA
Text: allocation of the land, buildings and service facilities, has

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 684) their possible future use under consideration.

Speaker: NA
Text: The Depanment of Manufacturing Industry is in continu-

Speaker: NA
Text: ous liaison with NASA on the phase-down, with a view to

Speaker: NA
Text: minimising its effect on the Carnarvon community.

Speaker: NA
Text: Island Lagoon-Trackin g Station

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 702)

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Street asked the Minister for Manufactur-

Speaker: NA
Text: ing Industry, upon notice:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Has the offer by the National Aeronautics and Space

Speaker: NA
Text: Administration to hand over the Island Lagoon tracking sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion been rejected by the Australian Government.

Speaker: NA
Text: the worst shortage of accom-

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) If so, has this rejection been described by senior

Speaker: NA
Text: research scientists as a short-sighted move which is a blow to

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian space researchers and to the cause of fundamen-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal research.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) What has happened to the 85ft radiotelescope at

Speaker: NA
Text: Island Lagoon.

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Enderby-Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's question is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) Yes, the offer by the United States National Aeronaut-

Speaker: NA
Text: ics and Space Administration (NASA) to hand over the

Speaker: NA
Text: antenna and some associated equipment and the buildings

Speaker: NA
Text: and services at the Island Lagoon tracking station was

Speaker: NA
Text: declined in September 1973. The reason for declining the

Speaker: NA
Text: offer was that the predicted level of Australian use would not

Speaker: NA
Text: have justified the cost of equipping the antenna for radio

Speaker: NA
Text: astronomy and maintaining the facility.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Such a statement was reponed in the Adelaide Adver-

Speaker: NA
Text: tiser of 10 October 1973. It was natural that the dismantling

Speaker: NA
Text: of the antenna should cause concern. However, it is pertinent

Speaker: NA
Text: to draw attention to the fact that facilities superior in many

Speaker: NA
Text: respects to those which were located at Island Lagoon exist

Speaker: NA
Text: at the NA'SA tracking stations in the Australian Capital Ter-

Speaker: NA
Text: ritory and are available for use by Australia. Over the past

Speaker: NA
Text: twelve months only two Australian scientists have used the

Speaker: NA
Text: antenna in the Australian Capital Territory wereas many

Speaker: NA
Text: more users could be accommodated. The costs to the users

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 701) are small and certainly insignificant compared with prorata

Speaker: NA
Text: sharing of the costs which would have been involved at

Speaker: NA
Text: Island Lagoon.

Speaker: NA
Text: (3) The struaure ofthe 26m (85ft) antenna at Island La-

Speaker: NA
Text: goon was sold and dismantled late in 1973. Most ofthe sta-

Speaker: NA
Text: tion electronic and antenna electro-mechanical equipment

Speaker: NA
Text: was removed for use at other NASA stations.

Speaker: NA
Text: Australian Capital Territory: Child Care

Speaker: NA
Text: Services and Facilities

Speaker: NA
Text: Mr Street asked the Minister for the Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory, upon nodce:

Speaker: NA
Text: WUl he support the establishment

Speaker: NA
Text: consultative committee on chUd care in the AustraUan Capi-

Speaker: NA
Text: tal Territory.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's quesdon is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: The Australian Government has under consideration the

Speaker: NA
Text: question of child care services and facUities on a nadonal

Speaker: NA
Text: basis. The honourable member will be aware of various

Speaker: NA
Text: reports, which the Government is considering. These reports

Speaker: NA
Text: and recommendations wUl doubtless have impUcations for

Speaker: NA
Text: the AustraUan Capital Territory.

Speaker: NA
Text: Officers of the Department ofthe Capital Territory are in

Speaker: NA
Text: regular communicauon with the relevant authorities in the

Speaker: NA
Text: field of child care and with the various local community

Speaker: NA
Text: organisations. At present, I do not see a need to establish a

Speaker: NA
Text: consultative committee but I will keep the possibility open.

Speaker: NA
Text: House of Referendum Referendum Referendum Referendum

Speaker: NA

Speaker: NA
Text: Tuggeranong: Housing

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 724)

Speaker: NA
Text: (Question No. 716) Mr MCLeay asked the Minister for the Capital

Speaker: NA
Text: Territory, upon nodce:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) What is the proportion of Government to private

Speaker: NA
Text: housing development in the new district of Tuggeranong.

Speaker: NA
Text: of a fully representative

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) What efforts have been made to ensure a diversi-

Speaker: NA
Text: fication of construction.

Speaker: Mr BRYANT
Text: Th e answer to the honourable

Speaker: NA
Text: member's quesdon is as follows:

Speaker: NA
Text: (1) The National Capital Development Commission's

Speaker: NA
Text: current plans envisage Government houses constituting

Speaker: NA
Text: approximately 30 per cent of the total Tuggeranong

Speaker: NA
Text: development.

Speaker: NA
Text: (2) Private housing construction provides a wide range of

Speaker: NA
Text: housing types. The National Capital Development Com-

Speaker: NA
Text: mission advises that a variety of designs wUl be used for

Speaker: NA
Text: Government housing. In addition sites will be available for

Speaker: NA
Text: lease for a variety of medium density housing developments

Speaker: NA
